DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS
CANADA

MEMORANDUM.

Mr. Scott,

Mr. Agent Ogletree forwards a recommendation from Rev. Father Ferrault, Winnipeg, for the appointment of Raoul Martel as teacher of the Lake Manitoba Indian Day School, and also a letter from Chief Moise Paul approving of his appointment.

Mr. Martel was in the service of the Department for sometime before he enlisted in 1915. He was re-appointed as teacher of this school in July, last, but the Indians protested his appointment on the grounds that he was drunk on the reserve several times. Chief Paul made the charge, but he now recommends that he be re-appointed. Father Ferrault says that the charges made against him were false and states that, as he was recently married, there will be no cause in future for such charges being made on account of his conduct, and that he is quite satisfied that he will give good satisfaction, if reappointed. Mr. Martel has Normal training and had several years experience as teacher in this school previous to his enlistment.

Henry Springer, who was the former teacher, has resigned from March 31st, last. As there is at present no teacher at this school, I would beg to recommend that Mr. Martel be given another chance at his retention of the position, however, to depend on his conduct and the success with which he meets in this work. The salary paid to Mr. Springer was at the rate of $500.00 per annum, and I would recommend that Mr. Martel receive the same rate of payment.

It will be necessary to fit up a residence for the teacher of this school. Father Ferrault last summer reported that he could purchase a house for $250.00, but would have to have it moved about three miles to the schoolhouse and it would cost about $100.00 to move it and fit it up.
He now states that, if the Department does not wish to carry out his suggestion, it will be necessary to build a residence, as it will be impossible to get a teacher unless suitable quarters are provided.

The school building also requires some repairs to the foundation and to be sided on the outside. The present building is of log construction and is not situated in a central locality. There are about thirty children of school age on the reserve.

The Agent does not furnish any information regarding a building for the teacher's residence or the fitting up of the school building, and I think that he should be asked to furnish a full report in the matter. In the meantime, in order that the children may not be deprived of an education, I would beg to suggest that Mr. Martel be appointed and take up his duties.

[Signature]

Ottawa, April 14, 1920.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 9th instant enclosing a recommendation from Rev. Father Perrault for the appointment of Mr. Martel as teacher of the Lake Manitoba (Dog Creek) Indian Day School and also a letter from Chief Moise Paul, in which he also recommends Mr. Martel's appointment and states that he has now no complaint against him.

In reply I beg to say that, in order that the school may not remain closed, the Department will approve of the appointment of Mr. Martel, to begin duties as soon as possible. His retention in the position will depend upon the success with which he meets and also his conduct on the reserve. The Department will allow him a salary at the same rate as was paid Mr. Springer, namely $500.00 per annum.

Father Perrault requests that a suitable residence for the teacher be provided, as there is very poor accommodation at the present time. He informs the Department last summer that a house could be purchased for $250.00, which would have to be moved about three miles, and it would cost about $100.00 to move it and fix it up. He states that quarters for a teacher are absolutely necessary, as it is impossible to keep a teacher at this school without living quarters being provided for him. You should furnish a full report regarding the question of obtaining a residence for the teacher and whether you think it worth while to follow Father Perrault's suggestion being carried out to purchase this house and have it moved, or whether you think it better to build a small residence near the school and the probable cost of erecting the same. You should state your views fully regarding the question of providing suitable accommodation for a teacher for this school.

Father Perrault states that the school building also requires to be repaired. You should furnish a report stating the repairs that are required to place the school in good condition and the probable cost of having the work done. You will be good enough to give this matter your prompt attention, in order that the Department can arrive at a decision regarding this matter.

In the meantime, as advised above, Mr. Martel may carry on the work as teacher.

Your obedient servant,

A. G. LeBreton,
Indian Agent,
Portage la Prairie, Man.

S. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Dear Sir,

I am in receipt of your letter dated May 11th informing me of the appointment of Mr. Matil as teacher of the Lake Manitoba Indian Day School. In the meantime, Mr. Ogilvie, Indian Agent informed me of the decision of the Department to reduce the salary to $500.00 per annum. I beg to say that Mr. Matil could not accept the position under his given $600.00 until Mr. Spring in last month. We pointed out since that time...
the high cost of living has not been reduced, and
the difficulties of communication have not changed
to wonder why you deemed expedient to reduce a
salary which was barely sufficient to support a fa-
mily.

Unless you pay $600.00 a year, he refuses the appoint-
ment and I am in the impossible position to secure an
another, and then the school has disappeared
cloud. It would be for a common laborer to
today securing at least $600.00 a year instead
but you should be well educated man, teaching
in a lonely and remote place at Dog Creek
get the same amount.

Hoping you will comply with my request and
so allow the Indians of the Dog Creek, have the
benefit of education.

Yours respectfully,

Sir,

In reference to cheque no. 22473 for $68.75 dated Dec 9th in favor of Mr. Smith (noted as such) I beg to state that according to "Rules and Regulations for Teachers" by which I understand that when a teacher (school) is paid a certain amount per day in proportion to the number of days (school days) in the year. As there are 200 school days in one year and as the salary is $68.75 per annum, the proportional amount for 22 days in September should be $13.75 per day, making a total of $66.50. If on the other hand the salary is computed at the rate of $68.75 for 11 months then, I was overpaid $2.25. It may be that I do not understand the Rules thoroughly, so I respectfully ask for information.

Will you also advise me if the bonus accorded to teachers is only payable yearly?

Thanking you in anticipation,

[Signature]

To the Secretary
Dept of Indian Affairs
Ottawa

Aug 15th 1920

Sir,

I have the honour to draw your attention to the fact that an error has been made in reference to my last cheque for quarter ended June 30th.

My salary is, outside of bonus and extra for distributing ratione, $156.00 per quarter. I have been advised by the Standard Bank at Erickdale to whom all my salaries and bonuses are assigned that they have received a cheque in my name for $237.00, a difference of $81.00 and above my regular salary, so presuming this is a clerical error, I am duty bound to report it to you.

Before proceeding as to the cause and means of giving back this amount, I also want to point out that an error was made last year, but at that time the error was not in my favour. This in no regard to the administration for distributing rations. The facts are these. For the months of Sept-Oct-Nov Dec 1920, the salary attached...
to which I was justly entitled was amply paid to some other person in settling very satisfactorily to the Defendant the sum of $16.67 should be deducted from the above mentioned sum viz $87.00 leaving a balance of $70.33 to be taken off any balance for the outstanding debt.

Before closing, I can only say that I only want what is just and equitable. And trusting this will meet with your approval.

I have the honour to be

Sir,

Your obedient servant

[Signature]

Ottawa, August 24, 1921

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 15th instant in which you state that you consider you have been overpaid for your services as teacher at the Lake Manitoba (Dog Creek) Indian Day School for the quarter ending June 30th, last.

In reply I beg to say that you began duties at this school on September 1, 1920 and for the period you taught the school during the month of September, 1920, you were allowed $63.75 ($2.125 per day from September 28, 1920.) You were also paid $150.00 for the December quarter and the same for the March quarter. As you had completed the full school year on June 30th, last, you were allowed the balance of your yearly salary, viz., $237.00. No overpayment was made you.

With reference to your statement that you were not paid your salary for dispensing rations for the months of September, October, November and December, 1920, I beg to say that you will be advised under separate cover.

OTTAWA, August 24th, 1922.

Sir -

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letters of the 19th instant, enclosing the resignation of Mr. R. A. Martel as teacher of the Lake Manitoba (Dog Creek) Indian Day School. It is noted that he desires his resignation to take effect from October 1st, next.

The Department will accept the resignation of Mr. Martel, but would prefer that he give up his duties before the close of June, so that the new teacher can take charge from the reopening of the school after the present summer holidays. However, this matter will be left in your hands.

The application which you forwarded from Mr. Maxime Goulet for the position as teacher at this school to succeed Mr. Martel is also received, together with recommendations from several persons regarding his fitness for the position. I am of the opinion for the appointment of Mr. Goulet, and he should take up duties immediately upon the retirement of Mr. Martel. The salary allowed will be at the rate of $600 per annum, plus any bonus provided by law.

If Mr. Martel teaches any part of the current quarter ending September 30th, next, he should prepare and forward his return through your office, in order that payment of salary and bonus due him up to the date of his resignation can be made.

You should inform Mr. Goulet that his appointment is approved, and that he should take charge when Mr. Martel leaves.

I shall be pleased if you will inform the Department of the date on which Mr. Martel gives up duties, and also the date on which Mr. Goulet begins.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLEAN

Acting Deputy & Secretary.

A. Ogletree, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Portage la Prairie,
Man.

OTTAWA, September 20, 1922.

Sir:

A communication has been received from Mr. R. A. Martel, who formerly taught the Lake Manitoba (Dog Creek) Indian Day School, regarding payment of his salary for part of the current quarter.

If you consider that any payment is due Mr. Martel for his services as teacher or for any other purpose, I have to request that you will forward your claim covering this amount due at an early date. In this connection I beg to refer you to official letter of August 24th, last, in which you were informed that the Department would accept his resignation, but would prefer that he gave up duties before the school re-opened on the 1st of September, last. If he did not teach during July or August, the annual summer holidays, it is not considered that he is entitled to any payment, but if he was acting as dispenser there may be a balance due him for that service.

You were requested to inform the Department the date on which Mr. Goulet, who was appointed to succeed Mr. Martel, began duties, and I would be pleased to have this information at an early date.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy Secretary.

Replying to your letter of the 12th instant, in which you claim a balance of salary for your services as teacher of the Lake Manitoba (Dog Creek) Indian Day School, I beg to say that we are referring this matter to Mr. Agent Ogletree, Portage la Prairie, for a report.

I may say, however, that if you did not teach any during the months of July and August, last, which comprise the annual summer holidays, it is considered that there is no further balance due you for that period. Ottawa, Nov. 7, 1928.

Sir:

I have your No. 208-14 of the 27th ultimo, covering the Provincial School Inspector's report on the Lake Manitoba Indian Day School, of the Manitowahp Agency. I have noted that the teacher, Mr. Maxime Goulet, is poorly qualified and in addition has very little equipment for the conduct of the day school.

In reply I beg to state that the Department is writing Mr. Agent Ogletree, asking him to give some attention to the Lake Manitoba School at this time and requisition for any material needed. Mr. Goulet's progress will be watched carefully and, if there is no marked improvement in the school, the church authorities will be asked to nominate another teacher.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Aas't Deputy & Secretary.

Regina, Sask.
Ottawa, Nov. 7, 1922.

Sir:

The Provincial School Inspector has reported on the Lake Manitoba Indian Day School. The Department learns that Mr. Goulet is not very satisfactory but that he may be helped somewhat by supplying the proper equipment. The Inspector states that the teacher had no idea of what books or programme he was to follow and was expecting orders from your office. He appears to be without an adequate supply of classroom equipment.

Kindly initiate a correspondence with Mr. Goulet or visit the school if you are in that vicinity, with a view to making it possible for him to show progress and good results in the work. The Department will fill any requisitions recommended by you, without delay.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

December 28th, 1932.

Gentlemen,

Replying to your letter of the 21st instant regarding H. A. Martell, I beg to say that previous to October 1st last this gentleman was a teacher on the Dog Creek Indian reserve. Since then he has disappeared and I am unable to give any information as to his present whereabouts. I would suggest that you communicate with Mr. A. Uglertree, Indian Agent, Portage la Prairie, Man., who, I think, will be able to give you the information you desire.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Deputy Superintendent General

Messrs. Dyke and Benson,
Barristers, etc.,
Fort William, Ont.
Subsequently, he advised me to put in another claim stating that at the time of my first demand he was not aware that I was entitled to my salary and that he would recommend the second claim for payment.

As I was not getting any news, I wrote Mr. Ogletree who finally answered that the Department had refused to change its decision and, as stated before, although I have complied with the regulations, I did not get my three months' salary and bonus and this possibly through a divergence of opinion on matters not pertaining in the least to the fulfillment of my duties as teacher.

I do not wish to argue the question on the merits of my case; I will only say that since I have the sympathy of such men as Messrs. Horace Chevrier, L.F. LAKE MANITOBA INDIAN DAY SCHOOL:

There is a day school on this reserve, which is taught by Mr. Maxime Goulet. At the time of my visit, the school was closed on account of an epidemic of measles amongst the children. There were 27 names on the register, 6 boys and 19 girls. The average attendance for the last quarter was 6, for the past year, 10.

The school is a log building 20 x 25 with shingle roof. It has a good high ceiling and is in a fair state of repair.

The teacher's residence is a log building 20 x 18 with an upstairs, but the walls being low, the upstairs can only be utilized for storing. It also has a lean-to kitchen 12 x 18. During the severe weather, the house is very cold, as it is lined on the inside with beaver board and I presume the plaster has crumbled away on the inside between the logs and the beaver board.

It is not necessary for me to say very much regarding Mr. Goulet's ability as teacher. I knew him when he was teaching school on this reserve about 35 years ago and at that time he was a man well up in years. Mr. Goulet is getting much too old for this work. The attendance at the school has been poor and I do not believe the children are making much headway.

Extract from Report of Inspector Bartlett on the Lake Manitoba Indian Day School - dated April 20th, 1926.

Maxime Goulet - Age 71.
Has taught for a number of years here, and at other points.
No special certification.
Health - Infirm.
Success - Extremely unsatisfactory.

The old gentleman is too infirm through age and ill-health to make a success, even if he had the natural ability and training.

I have considerable sympathy for the present incumbent. He is an old man, ill, with an ailing wife, alone in a very uninspiring environment. He is probably doing as well as he is able - but that unfortunately amounts to very little.

I have called his attention repeatedly that regulations call for the use of the text books of the public schools of the province; but he persists under various pretexts in using the books of a certain church society for readers. I see no hope of improvement under present conditions.

Should you decide to make any improvements in building, I should be glad to consult without charge to your Department.

In forwarding the above report under cover of his letter of April 29th, 1926, Commissioner Graham states as follows:

In 1922 the unsatisfactory conditions existing at this school were reported to you, and on the 7th of November you stated in letter No.126-6-1 that Mr. Goulet's progress would be watched carefully with a view to improving matters. Nothing further is there was not a marked improvement in the conduct of the school. Two years later, on the 19th of November, 1924, I again drew your attention to the very unsatisfactory report which had been received on this school, and pointed out that there was no change. To this letter I received no reply, and we are now in receipt of another report which, in my opinion, calls for prompt action.

This school should undoubtedly be closed up and the children transferred to a Roman Catholic Boarding School without delay. Some of them could be taken to Qu'Appelle School, and perhaps a few to Muscowequan, Pine Creek and Sandy Bay. I am quite satisfied there is a place for them if the Department decide that they should be sent to a Boarding School.

My dear Dr. Scott,

With further reference to the request which I made through you for the erection of a Boarding School on the Dog Creek Indian Reserve, may I say that I have since had the occasion to visit the Reserve. It seems to me that the position is ideal for a school of this kind. There are about 30 children of school age on the Reserve. Besides these there are also on the Rbb and Flow Reserve, and besides between Lake Manitoba and Winnipeg we have Catholic Indians on the Fisher River and the Jackhead Reserves. For these latter no provision whatsoever has ever been made, and this, it seems to me, is something that should engage the consideration of the Department. Let me add that the Sandy Lake School cannot accommodate the number of children who wish to enter and who have a right to depend upon it for an elementary education.

To my mind the construction of a Boarding School at Dog Creek would meet the situation and incidentally solve some other problems. It is absolutely necessary to erect new schools and new school buildings at Dog Creek and Rbb & Flow. The old school at Rbb & Flow is literally dilapidated to the department, and there is no school residence there at all. If the Boarding School be not undertaken, then it is imperative to attend at once to the other, and that would in the end be a sheer waste of public money. Moreover, the Boarding School would relieve you, I naturally suppose, from the necessity of having a Farm Instructor and Field Matron, as the object lesson would always be before the eyes of the people.
All in all, the project presents itself to me as a very desirable one. This is the only request I have ever made to the Department, and I would not make it, were I not convinced that the project were worthy of favorable consideration as a matter of public utility.

I beg to remain,

My dear Dr. Scott,

Very sincerely yours,

Acting on instructions received from the Officer Commanding Manitoba District, on the afternoon of the 13th inst., I proceeded by C.B.R. to Brickdale, Man., and on the following morning by hired livery to the residence of the farm instructor Dog Creek Indian Reserve, for the purpose of investigating a complaint that the above named Mr. Sanregret, teacher residing on the Reserve, had made wine and got drunk.

I first interviewed Mr. J. Knox, Riverman, Brickdale, Man., who was reported by Mr. Johnson, farm instructor to the Reserve, as having told him in the presence of Johnson's wife, that he had received a drink of wine at the teacher's residence. Knox stated that the drink he received from the teacher's residence was nothing more than fruit juice and water, jokingly referred to by the teacher and her maid as their wine, and that knowing the teacher and Mr. Johnson did not pull well together, he had asked Mr. Johnson if he had tried the teacher's wine and told he had had a short of it for a joke, not dreaming that Johnson would take him seriously. I later took a statement from Mr. Knox to this effect.

On arriving at the Reserve I proceeded to the Instructor's residence, and informing him of Mr. Knox's statement, asked him what other information he had regarding the teacher having got drunk, and whether the Indians had reported this. He informed me that some time back Miss Sanregret herself had told his wife that she had fixed up some plum juice which she was drinking it she had started to laugh and could not stop, this was the only information he had and he did not want his wife's name brought into the matter.

I then proceeded to the teacher's residence, and without giving her any names, told her that a complaint had been made that she was making wine and that the best way to clear the matter up was for me to search the premises, she I did but found no wine.

Miss Sanregret declared that there never had been any intoxicating liquor on the premises since she had resided there, and on being asked if she had ever fixed up any fruit juice she stated that the water was not fit to drink and that to make it palatable she had added fruit juice from preserved fruits, or rather she added a stock, and she thought she might have given rise to the story. Dear Mr. Graham:

I have been giving consideration to the education of Roman Catholic Indian children in the Lake Manitoba district, as I am desirous of determining a suitable site for a new school. At present time we have the Sandy Bay Indian Residential School and the Kibb and Ploy Indian Day School and a combined school at Crane River. In addition, there is the Lake Manitoba Indian Day School on the Dog Creek Reserve, on the eastern shore of the lake.

As I understand it, the buildings at the Sandy Bay Residential School are in fair shape, but the water supply is bad. Further, there is not sufficient accommodation there for the Roman Catholic children of the area who require residential school training. Your 309-11A R.C. 2, of September 16th, last, recommends that if the Sandy Bay School is to be rebuilt a better site should be secured. Good farm land and good water are of prime importance, and these are not found at the present site.

I may add, in confidence, that the Church is asking for the establishment of a new residential school on the Dog Creek Reserve. This request is not sponsored by any of the Missionary Orders and

W. M. Graham, Esq.,

I do not know what arrangements could be made for its conduct, if granted. Our census shows about 51 children of school age there.

My dear Dr. Scott,

I am in receipt of your letter of the 21st instant.

It does not appear to me to be wise to extend the Sandy Bay School. Your Indian agent at Portage la Prairie is of opinion that the Reserve should be moved farther North. I am not absolutely familiar with conditions, but this Reserve has always impressed me as having very little to commend it. If a suitable locality could be found elsewhere, it might be advisable to endeavor to move the Indians. With this prospect as a possibility, it would scarcely be wise to enlarge the school just now.

But this has nothing to do with my petition for a small school on the Dog Creek Reserve. I cannot thank you for your assurance that you are going to give my letter "consideration". May I add that the Sandy Bay and the Pine Creek (Groserville) Schools are in my jurisdiction. In these matters you deal, I understand, with the authority of the Church, and there is no one at Ottawa or elsewhere who is authorized to act for me.

My dear Archbishop Sinnett,

I must confess that I was rather disturbed by your letter, but your subsequent communication of March 29th allays the effect of your first communication. Mr. J. Waite, Indian Agent, Portage la Prairie, Man.

I desire to refer to your letter of October 18, in which you intimated that Sister Cecilia, assistant teacher at the Lake Manitoba reserve, was not returning to the day school and that her place had been taken by Sister Vergilla, of the same Order.

The last quarterly return from this school indicates that there are at present on the roll 16 pupils and there was an attendance of 16 when the public school inspector made his last inspection. In view of this relatively small enrolment it is exceedingly difficult to justify the employment of two teachers at this school. It is just possible, of course, that one of the teachers, probably the assistant, is engaged in welfare work or in providing nursing service on the reserve. If such is the case, this teacher, in my judgment, should be paid from either the Medical or the Welfare Vote. We have Indian day schools in the Dominion at this date with an average of 25 pupils, with one teacher in charge. It would be appreciated, therefore, if you could send forward in due course a report on this school and conditions on the reserve and a definite recommendation with respect to the employment of the assistant teacher.

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

STATEMENT OF GEORGE PAUL, March 16th, 1948

"A week ago last Saturday afternoon I saw Charlie Sutherland at the Charlie's place. Charlie Paul was with me and Elmo Heywood was there. Charlie Sutherland asked me to go with him but I told him that I was going with Jim Paul. We went to Charlie's place to look for a horse and Elmo Heywood was there. Charlie Sutherland went to the church. Jim Paul went to Jim Paul's place and I went to the church. Elmo had a horse and he told me to ride the horse. I went toward Jim Paul's place and met Jim Paul. Jim Paul told me to go and get a knife from Charlie Heywood's place. He wanted to cut the hobble off his horse's legs. I went out and got the knife and came back to the church. I met Charlie Sutherland by the church. He told me to watch the church. Elmo Heywood was there. We walked down the road back to the church. I heard Charlie Sutherland talking to someone near the church. I went inside the house and yelled out and I saw Charlie Sutherland coming down the road past Louis Chippeau's place. He said, "There is Elmo." I told him I hadn't seen Elmo. Charlie said, "Let's go and look for him." We met him by the church. Jim Sutherland called Elmo over to him and they talked together but I could not hear what they said.

Elmo Heywood called me. He said to me, "Do you want a drink?" I said, "That kind of beer have you got?" Jim Sutherland said it was just beer.

Elmo said to Jim Sutherland, "Let's drink with Jim Paul too." Sutherland said, "No. If we give him to drink Jim Paul will fight us when he gets drunk." Elmo said, "No, he won't fight us."

Elmo Heywood came and called me. I went outside and talked to Elmo. Jim Paul and Jim Sutherland went into the house. Elmo left and Jim Sutherland went back for Jim Paul and Jim Sutherland. We found him in the house. They had two 20 oz bottles of Bright's Wine. They had drunk some out of one bottle. The rest of us drank the two bottles of wine. Jim Sutherland went into the house and came back in about five or ten minutes with two more bottles of wine. We drank them. Then Jim Paul went with Jim Sutherland and in about ten minutes they brought back all bottles of wine. They gave us two bottles to drink and we were the six Elmo and Jim Paul and Jim Sutherland kept one bottle each back in the house. We drank all the wine out of the six bottles. Then I went to Charlie Sutherland's place and went to bed at about nine or ten o'clock."

SOUTH DRAKE:
SOUTH DRAKE: A padlock. The east door had been forced by breaking some framework near the back and breaking the window glass. One 20 gallon jug and fourteen 30 oz. bottles of Mass wine were stolen.

The Virginia, Joseph, and Father Archibald had left the premises on Sunday, July 15th, 1946, at about 6:00 P.M. We returned at about 11:30 P.M. on the following Monday. At this time I noticed the school had been entered. I notified the police at Asham by letter on July 15th, 1946.

I secured the window again by driving a nail in each side of the back and fastening the closed door with heavier wire. Everything else was left the way we found it as much as possible.

On Monday, July 16th, 1946, the windows were again left alone when we were absent from 11:30 A.M. to 6:30 P.M., then Father Archibald was coming to supper at about 7:00 P.M. He saw Jimmy Smith on the road talking to Jimmy Paul. Jimmy Paul was intoxicated.

He then checked the school and saw that the north west window was again missing. A large piece of glass had been broken enabling the intruder to glance inside to see what was in the safe. The cupboard at the back of the school had been forced open in the same manner as on the previous occasion.

Ten 20 oz. bottles of Mass wine were taken from the cabinet.

Jimmy Paul and Jimmy Sutherland are suspects in this matter. Jimmy Sutherland was seen by Elizabeth Ann, Mrs. Louis Gippins and Sheila Paul, Willie Baptiste and Mrs. Charlie Baptiste, drinking and gambling along the road on Saturday night.

On July 17th, 1946, we returned early from Asham. We spoke with the police. I noticed a small hole in one of the school seats. This hole had been kept in the cabinet and had been in its original position. It must have been caused by whoever broke into the school.

Sgd. Mr. K. Harpster.

1. The Lake Manitoba Bay School is a 20' x 24' frame building. The door is on the south side. There are two windows 30" x 36" on the south side. On the east side are four very small windows. On the west side are four windows each with 10 lights measuring 12" x 12". The most northerly of these latter windows is very badly had been made. There are several small marks on the window such that it had been painted. The window glass was carefully searched for possible fingerprints but with negative results. No other objects could be found in the school on which the culprit might have left prints. The present outside of the building is entirely covered with grass and vegetation. No evidence. Neither could any useful impression be found within the building.

2. Several small markings were noted on the cabinet door, possibly made with the blade of a knife or similar instrument. As far as can be ascertained there was nothing stolen other than the wine mentioned in the statement of Mr. K. Harpster. The missing wine is valued at $2.00.

3. A one gallon jug approximately one-third full of wine was handed in the police by Mr. K. Harpster.

The following self explanatory statement was taken from Mr. Johnson:

On the afternoon of Sunday, July 24th, 1965, an Indian or Indians came into the store. He was about 30 - 35 years old, with no distinguishing facial characteristics, wearing a cap and I don't remember how else he was described. He wanted to get a cheque cashed and showed me a cheque and produced a Registration Form as supplied by a Post Office where a Registration Certificate is issued. The name on this form was "Bill Miller" and was signed by Mr. Johnson. The cheque was one of the Royal Bank of Canada, Halifax, Nova Scotia Branch, NS, and it had an Erickdale return business stamp on the face of it. The Erickdale return stamp had the signature of either "Bill Miller" or "Bill Miller". This Indian who presented himself as Bill Miller endorsed the cheque on the back by signing the name "Bill Miller" from the Registration Form in his possession. At that time I thought this was a legitimate cheque and signed the Registration Form and placed the name "Bill Miller" on it as the Indians signature didn't compare very well with the writing of the name on the Registration Form.

I turned the cheque into the Bank of Commerce, Erickdale, NS, the same day, July 24th, 1965. Later it was returned from Winnipeg with the notation "no authority to sign".

I wrote a registered letter dated August 1st to Bill Miller, Erickdale, NS, and received notification that said letter had been delivered to Mr. Miller, Erickdale, NS. I am now holding Mr. Miller responsible for the delivery of my letter so he apparently received it at the Erickdale Post Office.

The Indians bought a pair of black jeans pants and a work shirt - color unknown. I think he got on the bus which left Erickdale at 11:30 A.M. each morning.

The cheque I gave over to the police is the cheque received from the man in question.

Mr. Miller was shown a group of photographs of Indians, Indian breeds and white persons. Among these was a photo of James SUTHERLAND, which SUTHERLAND picked up being a good resemblance of the man who came into our store. Mr. SUTHERLAND could not describe the man other than being a young Indian of medium stature, but he thinks it likely that he would recognize him if seen again.

I submit the following report on schools in the Portage la Prairie Agency inspected during November, 1946.

DOG CREEK INDIAN DAY SCHOOL

Sister Marguerita is in charge. Eighteen children are enrolled and 14 were present. The Grades are as follows:

- Grade 1 - 10
- Grade 2 - 5
- Grade 3 - 1
- Grade 5 - 2

The children were fairly well clothed and were clean.

The class-room was tidy and warm. The stove is cracked badly and should be renewed.

The school could be brighter and more cheerful if the walls received a coat of light paint. The Sister had some nice plants in the windows and this added greatly to the appearance.

The teacher's residence is in good repair. The cellar now has water in it to the depth of about three feet. A tank pump should be supplied so that the water could be pumped out. The walls of the cellar are filled up with dirt. A proper cement floor and walls were installed and a sump hole placed in one corner perhaps the basement could be kept fairly dry and thus be made useful for storing supplies and vegetables.

A school garden was broken up this year from new land and the Sister intends to have the children to gardening next spring. The vegetables will be used for their noon meal. If the basement under the house can be kept dry it will be used for storage purposes.

My dear Mr. Maybank,

In the Dog Creek Indian Reserve on Lake Manitoba there are something more than 40 children of school age. The clergy from Sandy Bay Residential School have gone into the Reserve during the last year and by solicitation have taken away 23 children. To my mind and, I think, to the mind of the Indian Department it is much better that the children should be educated at the Day Schools on the Reserve. When the time of schooling is over they are not strangers on the Reserve but they take their place naturally in the environment to which they have always been accustomed. On the contrary those from the Boarding School are strangers and they find it hard to get back to their natural environment.

Consequently there should be a two room school on the Dog Creek Reserve. The school that is there now and another, preferably the present Sisters' House, with the kitchen where the girls could be taught cooking and another room where they could be taught sewing, etc. The children thus would get a practical education. May I ask you to submit this to the Authorities of the Indian Department.

Very sincerely yours,

(Sgd.) Alfred A. Sinnott

Dear Ralph:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of November 13th and also a letter received by you from Archbishop Sinnett sent forward therewith.

The Superintendent of Welfare and Training informs me that it is his intention to build six or seven Indian day schools in the province of Manitoba during the coming fiscal year. The records here, however, do not indicate that a request for the establishment of a school at the Dog Creek Reserve has been received either from Indian Agent Waite or Inspector Hamilton. It is just possible, though, that if the needs of the Indians are more than they appear to be at other reserves, a switch might be made. This is a matter that I would be glad to discuss with you personally immediately following your arrival at Ottawa for the Session. I am disposed to agree with the Archbishop that in view of all the circumstances, it would be sound policy to make provision for the education of the children at Dog Creek on their own reserve.

I am returning Archbishop Sinnett's letter herewith.

Yours sincerely,

Re: 126-16-1 (W.T.) November 20, 1947.

With reference to the above-named letter and enclosure, being a letter addressed to Mr. Maybank, M.P., by His Grace Archbishop Sinnott, I beg to advise that there are 45 children of school age on the Lake Manitoba Reserve. Of these, 18 are at the Day School and 23 at Sandy Bay Residential schools. Of the four remaining, 2 are in Winnipeg and two at Pine Falls. Both families are resident at the points mentioned.

At the present time there are two sisters and a resident priest on the Lake Manitoba Reserve. The idea is to increase the community, as two sisters find it difficult to live together. Two additional sister teachers would make for a better and more congenial life. However, to build an additional school on the present site, would be of no help to the Indian children, who are walking from four to five miles to the school. While the suggestion of teaching cooking, sewing etc., may be sound, it still would be necessary to transport children to and from school if an addition on the present site was contemplated.

No provision was made in Estimates for an additional school at Lake Manitoba. If it is the intention of the Department to build at Lake St. Martin next year and consideration given to the building of Day Schools at Crane River, Long Plain and Sandy Bay Reserves, it would appear that these would constitute a full building program for some years to come.

J. White, Indian Agent.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 26th instant, with reference to the amount of salary paid you for the quarter ending June 30, 1922.

In reply I beg to say that you began duties at the Lake Manitoba Indian Day School, at a salary of $600.00 per annum, on September 1, 1920. The school year in Indian day schools begins September 1st and ends June 30th, and, as you were a new teacher at the Lake Manitoba School, you were paid for the quarter ending September 30, 1920, for the number 87 days you actually taught, an amount of $65.00.

For the December quarter 1920, you were paid one-quarter of your yearly salary, or $150.00, and for the March quarter 1921, you were paid the same amount.

When we received your return for the quarter ending June 30, 1921, (the end of the school year) it was found that you had taught the required number of days during the school year and, as you have previously been paid $265.00, the Department paid you the balance of your yearly salary, namely, $237.00.

For the school year just closed, which began September 1, 1921, and ended June 30, 1922, the Department paid you as follows:

- September quarter, 1921, .............. $150.00
- December quarter, 1921, .............. $150.00
- March quarter, 1922, .............. $150.00
- June quarter, 1922, .............. $150.00

You have, therefore, been paid the full amount of salary due you.

There is still due you the bonus for the quarter ending June 30, 1922. The method of payment of bonus to teachers of Indian day schools for the fiscal year 1922-23, (which began April 1, 1922) has not yet been decided upon. As soon as a decision is made the bonus due you for the June quarter will be paid.

It was my duty last fall to visit a number of Indian schools in the Selkirk district in Manitoba. I wish to refer again to conditions in the Big Creek school.

The visit of Mr. Christenson and Mr. Waite, paying treaty trips, brought it again to my mind. Mr. Christenson said that the matter of a new school for Big Creek was under consideration.

The school building there is of log and much like the homes of the Indians themselves. It is very difficult to heat, and the lighting is very poor. There is no porch on the door, and the draft keeps the floor cold. The residence of the teacher and her companions is unfit for two young ladies to try to live comfortably in. I feel sure that conditions in the school room and in the house are responsible for attacks of illness from which the teacher suffered.

The teacher, Miss Longpre, used modern methods in teaching and has been getting good results comparatively speaking. I trust that her health will permit her to remain.

I might mention again the long distances some of the pupils had to go, and back home to travel in the early winter snow, walked from four to seven miles. I believe some others are now in boarding school.

I trust that your department will improve the situation.

Yours truly,

DOG CREEK DAY SCHOOL

This school is taught by Miss May J. Sanregret, and she has been provided with a helper. There are 26 children on the register, and three more will be ready to start after the holidays. There are also some children from this reserve attending the Sandy Bay Boarding School. Miss Sanregret is getting splendid results, as before she took charge this place was dormant as far as the teaching was concerned. Not only is she getting splendid results as a teacher, but she has helped the Farming Instructor a great deal where there has been sickness on the reserve, and I cannot speak too highly of her work. This opinion is borne out by the report of Public School Inspector Flewis, who has charge of that district. A lot of the children from the south end of the reserve come to school a distance of five miles, and some from the north end about two or two and a half miles. Inspector Flewis recommends a van for conveying the children from the south end to and from the school, and I am submitting this for the consideration of the Department.

The school and teacher's residence are very poor affairs. The worst feature of both buildings is that they are practically unfit for habitation in the winter. The teacher informed me that it was always noon before they could get any heat in the school at all, and the house is also extremely cold. For this reason, I believe, the present teacher is resigning from the work, which is regrettable, but she informed me that she had pretty nearly made up her mind that she could not put in another winter there, as her health would not permit her to stay. Owing

Sir:

I beg to bring to your attention the fact that eight children of from 7 to 10 years of age have to walk over the lake on the Lake Manitoba Reserve a distance of 6-8 miles daily, and return home the same distance. The parents of these children are engaged in fishing and are on the lake early in the morning and cannot arrange to take the children to school. I beg to recommend that a sleigh be hired to take these children back & forward, the cost would be $2.00 per day, the sleigh would be driven by an aged Indian. Will you please advise in this matter.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

Ottawa, November 25, 1930.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 24th inst., informing the Department that a number of children have to walk a considerable distance in order to attend the Lake Manitoba Indian Day School, and recommending that a sleigh be hired to drive these children to and from school each day.

In reply I have to say that our funds for the balance of the present fiscal year are entirely assigned, and we are unable to provide the cost of engaging the services of the Indian referred to by you. Would it not be possible for the parents to arrange to have these children taken to and from school? Please make enquiry and see if the parents could not provide the necessary facilities.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. McKenzie,
Secretary.

Miss K. C. Weber is a qualified teacher, and I would expect fair results from her efforts. The teacher's residence is well furnished, and is occupied by Miss Weber and Miss Doiron, who prepares the noon-day meal for the children and acts as Field Matron. These two women do very well, but I would consider that a married man could fill this position much better and would be more capable of looking after the work, as well as attending to the outside matters which arise both about a school and residence.

A large patch of plaster has fallen off the school ceiling, and more is loose. This repair work should be attended to during the coming season. The residence has no eavetroughing, consequently the rain water from the roof seeps in around the foundation and floods the basement. As a protection to the foundation and basement, eavetroughing should be supplied.
LAKE MANITOBA INDIAN DAY SCHOOL.

I arrived here at noon on the day previous to Good Friday, and found the children dismissed for the day. The roll calls for 26 pupils, 8 boys and 18 girls. The grades are as follows:

Grade I - 9
" II - 6
" IV - 10
" V - 1

The average attendance for the quarter ending March 31st, was 18.03. Some of the children have a long distance to come, and the 'flu and bad colds had greatly reduced the attendance.

Miss K. C. Weber
Regina, Sask., April 20, 1951.

Dear Mr. Scott:

I am enclosing herewith a report on the various schools in the Portage la Prairie and Manitowah Agencies. This report was made by Mr. Inspector Hamilton, who was occupied from the 26th February to the 14th April in making an inspection of these two agencies.

The Inspector points out that the Lake Manitoba Day School was closed on the day prior to Good Friday. I do not know why this should be. The attendance here is fair. The Inspector points out that while the teacher is certified, he is of the opinion that a married man could fill this position much better. I do not agree that I can agree with him in this. We have had some splendid results with two girls working in these schools, in fact better than when we had a man. We have nothing in the estimates to provide for repairing the interior of this school. I note the Inspector states that a large patch of plaster has fallen off the ceiling and more is loose.

On the whole I would say that the report on these schools is very satisfactory.

Yours very truly,

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

Sir:

I beg to enclose report on the Lake Manitoba Day School for the month of May 1934. I also beg to make requisition for the sum of $15.00 for the digging of stones in the school-yard. It is about six years since the school was built and since that time the stones in the yard have raised and the yard is dangerous for children playing games. The smaller stones have been picked by the teacher and children but there are some requiring a team and men to haul away. Most of the large stones will weigh in the neighbourhood of half a ton.

The teachers made the request that a porch be built at the back door of the residence. The back door faces North and during the winter it is impossible to keep the kitchen warm with one stove and an additional heater takes up too much room. The porch could also be used for storing wood and the meat for the children's mid-day meals. The porch required would be 8 X 10 X 9, the material required as follows:

- 13 pcs. 2 X 4 X 10, 300 ft., 6" siding, 90 ft. flooring,
- 200 ft. sheeting, 750 shingles, 1 roll tarpaper, 1 window
- 6X8 - 4 light, labour, nails etc. The approximate cost $60.00.

Will you please advise in these matters.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa

FROM THE TEACHER OF THE Lake Manitoba Indian Day School
ORIGINAL ON FILE NO. 126-6-4A

The Teacher requests the following:

Window Shades, Cream, 36 in.wide 4
Front Door Lock- Yale 1
Wood screws, 1½ in. 7 doz.

The lean-to, which we use as a store-room for our provisions, leaks badly. At present we cannot keep anything in the cellar as the water is 4 ft.high. Hence if the Lean-to were repaired our problem would be solved for spring and fall, as the cellar floods at these seasons.
Ottawa,
July 26, 1943.

EX'D.
A

Mr. J. Waite, Indian Agent, Portage la Prairie, Man.

With reference to requisition for supplies for the Lake Manitoba Day School, you may purchase the following:

- 4 Window shades, cream, 35" wide
- 1 Front door lock, Yale
- 7 Doz. wood screws, 1½"
- 1 Gal. flat wall paint, cream
- 1 Gal. varnish, light oak
- 2 Gal. turpentine
- 2 Brooms

The following is a quotation from the teacher's requisition:

"The lean-to, which we use as a store-room for our provisions, leaks badly. At present we cannot keep anything in the cellar as the water is 4 ft. high. Hence if the lean-to were repaired our problem would be solved for spring and fall, as the cellar floods at these seasons."

I presume from the above that the cellar to which the teacher refers is the cellar in the teacher's living quarters. It is too bad that some arrangements could not be made to drain out this water, because, for sanitary and health reasons, it is regrettable that this amount of water is continually standing in the cellar. However, if this cannot be done you should make immediate arrangements to repair the lean-to which is used as a store-room for the teacher's provisions.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Portage la Prairie,
Manitoba.

July 29, 1943.

The Secretary, Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

Re: 126-6-5, July 26, 1943.

With reference to the last two paragraphs of the above mentioned letter, I wish to advise that owing to the high water level in the lake district this year all cellars in the vicinity of Lake Manitoba are flooded. To pump the water out of the cellar would not benefit, as it would immediately fill in again.

During treaty payments on the Lake Manitoba Reserve, I checked over the lean-to roof, and found the radio pole had been nailed to a piece of plank which was nailed to the roof. This allowed water to back up under the shingles and leak through the sheeting. This was remedied and I have heard no further complaint.

J. Waito,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir,

In reply to yours of the 7th inst., I wish to inform you that the Indian Department does not provide the wood supply necessary for heating the residence at the Lake Manitoba Indian Day School.

We, the Benedictine Sisters, took charge of the Lake Manitoba Indian Day School in September 1935. Ever since then we have provided and paid for the fuel for the school residence out of our salaries. During the year, with an average winter, we used about 20 to 25 cords of wood. Last year we used 25 cords, the winter being most severe. We use our own fuel supply to cook the hot lunches for the school children during the winter months. For the current year, we have already purchased 10 cords of wood for the residence.

Thanking you for your kind consideration,

I remain,

Yours truly,

Sr. M. Margarita m.

Mr. A. G. Hamilton, Inspector of Indian Agencies,
538 Dominion Public Building, Winnipeg, Manitoba.

I desire to refer to my letter to you, dated September 16, 1942, copy of which I am sending forward herewith.

The officials at the Minister's office are anxious to know what action you took to provide the wood necessary for the heating of Indian day schools and teachers' residences attached thereto, immediately following receipt of this communication.

The Minister is in receipt of a letter in which the statement is made that no fuel has been supplied to heat the teacher's residence at the Lake Manitoba Indian Day School, despite the fact that an amount of the fuel purchased by the teacher is used to heat and prepare noonday lunches for the pupils. May I point out also that when teachers' salaries are under review from year to year the amount of salary is, to some extent at least, determined by the housing accommodation provided for the teacher and the supply of wood allowed. We were under the impression here that all Indian day schools and all teachers' residences in Manitoba were heated with wood or other fuel. The information contained in the letter to the Minister, in respect to the Lake Manitoba Indian Day School, came as a great surprise to the officials. We are anxious, therefore, that you should send forward, just as soon as you can conveniently do so, a list of the Indian day schools and teachers' residences in Manitoba and the provision that has been made in each case to supply these buildings with fuel.

Encl.

R. A. Hoey
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Ottawa, December 28, 1944.

Mr. J. Waite, Indian Agent, Portage la Prairie, Man.

In reporting on a recent inspection of the Lake Manitoba Indian Day School, Inspector Bartlett writes:

1. "Stove too high off floor, so that there is a layer of cold air on the floor most of the day. Soot clogs the base of the chimney flue, preventing its drawing the cold air off floor, and also adding to the fire hazard. This should be supervised."

2. "Wash dishes are supplied but need supervision as pupils have a tendency to leave dirty water standing, or even for different pupils to wash in the same water. Individual towels, or at least small face cloths, should be made available, either by the Department or by arrangement with parents of pupils."

3. "Cover of stove badly damaged. It should be replaced."

Suggestions Numbers 1 and 3 should receive your immediate attention. With regard to suggestion No. 2, you may purchase whatever amount of towelling you consider necessary.

The Inspector states that there is a fire extinguisher in the school, but he does not know when it was recharged. If refills are necessary for this extinguisher, you may purchase same.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

My dear Mr. Waite:

I am very anxious about the building of another school on the Dog Creek Indian Reserve, or rather I should say about the establishing of another school. The present residence of the Sisters would be used for the second school. They could have a class in Domestic economy in one room, a class of manual labor in another, a class of knitting and sewing in another, and finally a class of cooking in another. The Indian children are much better when they are educated on their own reserves. They are in constant contact with their parents and what they learn at school they communicate at once to their parents. The Indian Residential School may have its good purpose, but it cannot do the work of the Day School on the Reserve.

I understand that you said that other Reserves might come before Dog Creek, because they did not have in their proximity a good Residential School like Sandy Bay. To me that is not pertinent at all. What is pertinent is that the Day School does not cost as much as the Residential one. Why should there be twenty Indian children at Sandy Bay, when they can be educated better and with less cost in their own Day School on the Dog Creek Indian Reserve? I see no reason why the Department should not convert the Sisters' Residence into another school and build another residence for the Sisters. At the moment there is more than a foot of water in the basement of the Sisters' present residence. The new residence could be built on higher ground. I think these arguments are most convincing.

Very sincerely yours,

Alfred A. Sinnott,
Archbishop of Winnipeg.

Ottawa, October 25, 1948.

Re: Lake Manitoba Indian Day School,
Fortage la Prairie Indian Agency,
Vogar, Manitoba.

With reference to Mr. Hoey's memorandum dated August 25th, a report has now been received from Mr. Gow's office in this matter.

The present siting of the school is excellent; it is on the highest ground in the property; there is no complaint regarding it.

However, Mr. Davis was referring to the Sisters' Residence. This is a frame structure over a small cellar pit. This latter is subject to intermittent flooding which interferes with its essential use as a root store. But this flooding evidently does not affect the building itself, and no damage to the residents' health has so far been mentioned.

Three alternative solutions to this difficulty are suggested:

1. Install a drain from the cellar to a roadside ditch; estimated cost $350.00.
2. Fill in cellar pit and provide new storage cabin nearby; estimated cost $300.00.
3. Move entire residence to a new site over a concrete basement; estimated cost $2,400.00.

From a careful consideration of the factors involved, it is our opinion that the 2nd alternative is to be preferred. There is a definite need for storage space for garden produce, etc., for winter use as the property is 25 miles by road from the railway station and they are subject to considerable isolation during the winter. Judging from Mr. Gow's Report and the drawing accompanying it, a copy of which is forwarded herewith, the Residence will continue to be satisfactory if the cellar is filled in.

It is considered that this matter can be handled by Mr. Davis on your authority.

T.S. Mills,
Chief Engineer.

Sir,

I have the honour to reply to your letter of the 19th Oct. (No. 118342) as follows:

In regard to the method I have followed to arouse the interest of the parents and children in school matters, kindness and persuasion has been my two leading factors.

I never flatter them, but give them credit for any meritorious act they have done, and gently, but firmly correct them when they have done anything contrary to common decency. Whenever a child absents himself or herself from school I invariably make it a point to visit the home, and find out the cause, if I find no definite reason, but simply indolence, I sit down a reason with the parent, as a kind and just father would do to his child, and this method I have found out to work satisfactorily. I have also found out that long experience in Indian work that it is absolutely useless trying to drive an Indian to do this or that thing, lead him, and him by kindness and firmness in my principles and I have found to advantage that this is the only way.

Dear Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 15th last in reference to the alleged complaint of myself as teacher in the Lake St. Martin Indian school.

The late Chief, Sam Macdonald, made a similar complaint to Mr. Inspector Jackson once before, not that I neglected my duty as teacher, but he (S.M.) thought it would be better that I should live on the Reserve. I do not know if Mr. Jackson reported this or not. However, I have heard nothing further until now. But from the tone of your letter it would appear that I was neglecting the work. I have my instructions direct from the Department through you, and I guide myself accordingly which I suppose is all that was expected of me. However, the Indians will have to provide a suitable house for the teacher, if they think it is necessary he must live amongst them, but I doubt if it would be to their advantage, as I cannot be more for their welfare than I am doing now. And further I have been told and I must live without two months on any place (I want to prove why) but to make matters mutually satisfactory to all parties concerned, I will willingly live on the Reserve providing a suitable building is supplied to me (or during the winter months) and I think the Department will not object on account of the request, as I cannot afford to lay out money on a dwelling house without knowing how to get my own back.

I beg to remain your obedient servant,

J.W.C. Havell,
Teacher.

For years this school has remained stationary. At every visit I find conditions just about the same; three-fourths of the pupils are in the lowest grade and 2 or 3 in a higher grade, and it would appear just as soon as the boys and girls get so that they can do some work they are not sent to school. I would like to see a truant officer appointed on this reservation for a year and compel the larger children to attend. I have spoken to the chief and band elders about this matter of keeping the larger children away from school on many occasions but with no good result. The Chief, Charles Sumner, is an intelligent and go-ahead man. He sees the difficulty but is not able to enforce the attendance of these larger children. The attendance as shown by the school registry office for the year ending September 30th, 1920, is as follows: December 15, 1919, 18.44; March 1920, 19.65; June 23.09 and September 21.85; an average for the year of 21.66, and 80 per cent. of this attendance was in the kindergarten or the A.B.C. class.

INSPECTOR OF SCHOOLS, ERIEDEALE, Man.,
dated January 24, 1927.

You will be pleased to hear that all the schools have made good progress during the year. Fairford operating under most favorable conditions still holds the lead, but it is being overtaken by Lake St. Martin School, though Mr. Garwood works alone there with scanty equipment, unfavorable environment and a heavy ungraded school. All are doing well, however. Mr. Wheaton, of Little Saskatchewan, has done much more efficient work this year and the school shows substantial progress.
LAKE ST. MARTIN DAY SCHOOL.

The school is a log building in a good state of repair. There are 39 children enrolled, the average attendance being about 30. There were 35 present at the time of my visit. This school is taught by Mr. G. Garwood who has been here for 5 years. I first visited this school a year ago. Before going there, Mr. Ogletree, the Agent, gave me to understand that the teacher was worse than useless, and I no doubt went there with that in my mind. However, I changed my opinion considerably while I was there but did not like to say very much about Mr. Garwood in my last report on this school. However, after enquiring thoroughly into this man's work, I have come to realize that we have a first class teacher here. He is very much interested in his work; I spent a couple of hours in the classroom and in my opinion the children did very well and showed great improvements over last year. Mr. Garwood also does a lot of work on the reserve when there is sickness and co-operates in every way with Mr. White, the Farming Instructor.

A mid-day lunch is served to the children and on the day I was there it consisted of a thick soup with a little meat in it, some rice and evidently flour had been put in to make it thick. Each child also received two biscuits.
two biscuits and a cup of Cocoa. This mid-day meal at the school is certainly a splendid thing and is just what the children need. The cost is small but it certainly is of great benefit to the children, who, in many cases, do not receive sufficient food at home.

I regret to state that though I have made great efforts I have not as yet been able to light upon a suitable teacher for the school at Lake St. Martin. Mr. John E. The distribution of medicine, etc., for many years was attended to by the Missionary at Fairford but for some time it has been done by the teachers at the "Improved School". I am writing to ask whether without disturbing your finances arrangements could be possible to revert to the old method. I ask this for two reasons. In the first place, it is claimed that during the summer months, when the school is closed and the teachers are absent, the handling of the medicines is not done and the Indians complain. In the second place, the Indians around Fairford make such a poor living that they are not able to supplement the salary of the missionary as they should and the addition of the remuneration you are doing to them cannot fail to be of great assistance to Mr. Smith. I do not wish this done if the transfer will affect the salaries of the teachers at the Improved School, which I understand continues to go on so well, but all the same the transfer would be very satisfactory to me. I entered the service of the Department on July 1st, 1894, commencing duties as teacher at Little Sandy Bay reserve on Lake St. Martin, now officially known as Little Saskatchewan Reserve, on July 17th, 1894.

I was transferred to Lake St. Martin reserve, Oct. 1st, 1897.

I remained in the service of the Department as Medical Dispenser until Sept. 30th, 1916, relinquishing my connection with the Dept. then, as I could not conveniently find storage room for the rations distributed to the indigent Indians.

Manitoba. April 7, 1933.

Mr Agent Waite
Portage la Prairie.

Dear Sir,

I find that I cannot finance my contemplated trip to the Old Country unless I can have my salary cheque for the June quarter ahead of time. The amount that I now have on hand is barely sufficient to cover ocean fare without allowing for railway journey and the many incidental expenses on route. Therefore, I wonder if you would be able to advise the Department if I could have special consideration in this regard, and have my cheque a month ahead of time. This would relieve me of much anxiety and I could then proceed to book my passage without delay.

Thanking you, I beg to remain

Yours very truly

[Signature]
Teacher.

SS-10

April 15th, 1933.

Sir:

I beg to herewith enclose a letter received from Mr. Sam Waller, Teacher, Lake St. Martin's Day School, in which he requests that his cheque for the quarter ending June, 1933 be forwarded a month ahead of time, so that he may book his passage to England. I would advise that Mr. Waller is doing excellent work, not only as a teacher, but his work amongst the sick has made a considerable saving to the Department. Will you please advise in this matter.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,

Ottawa.
Ottawa, April 21, 1933.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 15th instant, enclosing a communication from Mr. Sam. Waller, teacher of the Lake St. Martin Indian Day School, requesting that his cheque for the quarter ending June 30th, next, be forwarded a month in advance, in order that he can arrange for his expenses in making a proposed visit to England.

In reply I have to say it is regretted that the cheque for the full quarter's salary cannot be sent in advance, as the Auditor General would take exception to the payment. However, we will forward Mr. Waller a cheque for one-half the quarter's salary about the middle of May, next, and the balance can be paid upon receipt of his return at the end of June.

Your obedient servant,

J.-B. Sutherland,
For Supt. of Indian Education.

Dear Sir,

I learn from Mr Garwood, the former teacher at the Lake St Martin Bay School, that there are no carpenters tools that I could use at this school, so I am wondering if the Department could provide me with something similar to enclosed advertisements clipped from the T Eaton catalogue of the Winnipeg Store. I hardly think there is any need for a more expensive set as these should give good service and seems to contain a very complete assortment.

I have written to His Grace, the Archbishop of Rupert's Land to see if he could obtain from his Diocese a small grant towards furnishing this place with the larger items of furniture needed, but some of the smaller articles can be made by me and painted to suit my own particular fancy. I have not yet had a reply from him.

Owing to limited means, I am not able at this time to make any great outlay, but with the things I already have, and with what the Archbishop may be able to get for me I hope to make myself very comfortable. A set of tools will always be useful not only to a resident teacher but to the pupils as well when there is an opportunity for manual handicraft.

If the Indian Agent has recommended any painting to be done either inside or outside the School dwelling, if the Department provides the paint, I would be quite willing to do this myself in my spare time, as I rather enjoy painting.

Believe me to be,

Yours truly

Sam Wallis
Ottawa, August 1, 1930.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 31st ultimo, requesting that a supply of carpenter's tools be provided for use at the Lake St. Martin Indian Day School, and enclosing clippings from the T. Eaton catalogue giving prices, etc.

In this connection I have to say that the Department is communicating with Mr. Agent Waite, Portage la Prairie, and authorizing him, after consulting you in the matter, to arrange for the purchase of carpenter's tools to an amount not exceeding $25. You should call at the office of Mr. Waite, in Portage la Prairie, on your way to the school. We are sending him the clippings which you forwarded. Mr. Waite will arrange for the purchase of tools not exceeding the above amount, after you inform him what you require.

Relative to furnishings for the teacher's residence, I have to say that the Department is not aware as to what supplies of this nature are in the residence. I may say that a new building was erected as a teacher's residence in the summer of 1927. After you arrive at the school, should you require a new supply of furnishings, you may prepare a requisition and forward same through the office of Mr. Waite. If possible, you should state the prices of the various articles. You should also, at the same time, requisition for any paint that may be required. It is noted that you would be willing to perform the labour in carrying out the painting.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

I have your letter of the 8th instant, enclosing a requisition from Mr. S. Waller, teacher of the Lake St. Martin Indian Day School, for furniture for the use of the teacher's residence and also carpenter tools.

In connection with the carpenter's tools asked for, I would refer you to official letter or the last ultimo in which you were authorized to incur an expenditure not exceeding the sum of $25 in the purchase of the tools as selected by Mr. Waller. You should consult him as to the various tools he requires and arrange for the purchase to an amount not exceeding the above mentioned sum. The Department understands that Mr. Waller intends to conduct a class in manual training and that these tools are required for this purpose.

Relative to the furnishings for the teacher's residence, you may arrange for the purchase, at the lowest possible cost, of a cook stove and a box stove, both of a wood burning type that would be satisfactory for the purpose for which they are required. Please arrange for the purchase and delivery of the above authorized supplies as soon as possible.

Sir:

Mr. Sam Waller is the teacher in charge here. The school was closed for Easter holidays, so I can make no remarks in regard to the progress of the children.

The school is a big building with a dining room on the rear. The building is in fair repair, and I found the place very tidy.

There are 38 pupils on the roll, and the grades range from Grade I to Grade III.

The teacher's residence is a five roomed house, which I found to be well furnished and spotlessly clean. Mr. Waller is a bachelor. He does all his own work.

Sir:-

Mr. Sam Waller is the teacher in charge. The roll calls for 46 pupils - 21 girls and 25 boys. The grades are arranged as follows:

Grade I = 33
" II = 7
" III = 1
" IV = 5

I found 25 pupils present and the average for the past quarter was 24.5.

The children were clean and fairly well dressed. In appearance, they were not as tidy as at some of the schools. I checked their work books and found them neat and the work nicely set down. They appear fairly well along in their grades, but are shy and do not speak out clearly. Mr. Waller takes a keen interest in his work and I believe satisfactory progress is made.

The building is of log construction. All the windows are on one side and it was quite easy to see the blackboard from any seat. The seats are the old double style, but in fair repair.

The children are provided with a noon lunch, consisting of soup and biscuits. The soup is discontinued as soon as the warm weather starts. The dishes are washed and put neatly away by the girls.

Wood is supplied by the Indians at no cost to the Department. The school will need whitewashing again this summer.

Ottawa, August 6, 1935.

Sir:

Mr. S. Waller, teacher of the Lake St. Martin Indian Day School, visited the Department several days ago. He states that the chimney of his residence, in its present condition, might cause fire to be starting. I have to request, therefore, that you will arrange to have the necessary repairs made. It may be necessary to demolish the present chimney and build a new one. You should engage the services of a competent man to do the work - you to purchase any brick, lime, etc., that may be required. I would urge you to have this chimney placed in good condition at an early date. Please forward an account, in triplicate, properly certified, covering the cost of any material and labour.

Referring to official letter of the 10th ultimo, in which you were authorized to supply a quantity of lime, whitewash brushes, towels and nails, it was stated in this letter that the teacher was to perform the work of whitewashing and re-chinking the outside of the school building. The teacher states he is unable to do this work, and you may therefore engage the services of Indians. If possible, the work should be completed before the school re-opens after the present summer holidays. No doubt, the farm instructor could oversee the job.

When forwarding accounts, in triplicate, for the labour, you should state definitely the number of days or hours employed and the rate paid.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

Re: 127-7-5 W T l, July 15, 1946.

I beg to acknowledge receipt of the above noted letter regarding a well at the teacherage, Lake St. Martin Reserve. It is true that the water in Lake St. Martin is not fit for drinking purposes, although the Indians drink it. Ice is packed for the teacherage, but this is not entirely satisfactory.

Some years ago an attempt was made to drill a well at the teacherage on this reserve. Four inch casing was used and a stop had to be made at 100 feet as the casing was too light to stand further drilling and the casing was pulled out.

At the present time there is an experienced driller on the Little Saskatchewan Reserve, drilling a well for the proposed nursing station. His costs are as follows and attached hereto is his price.

$7.50 per foot, including cost of 5" standard casing, board and lodging and the cost of moving. The Department of National Health and Welfare are paying the moving costs from Winnipeg to Little Saskatchewan Reserve and return.

It was expected that water would be obtained on this reserve at a depth of approximately 100 feet. The soil, however, appeared to be of the same constituency all the way down the 100 foot hole that was drilled some years ago. It is possible that water would be found if drilling could have been continued to a depth of 150 feet. The wells in the district are from 60 to 200 feet. The cost of a well would be high and I would suggest that if drilling is to be done on this reserve...
that a new hole, a distance from the old one, be drilled. The old hole was filled in as it was dangerous for stock.

Mr. Mills has a number of jobs in the environs of the City of Winnipeg and is anxious to return, but would be prepared to do this job if approved by the Department. It is expected that the well at the nursing station will be completed on or about the 26th of this month and if the Department intend to have a well drilled at this point immediate action is necessary.

A dug well is out of the question as only surface water can be obtained by this method.

J. Waite,
Indian Agent.

Mr. J. Waite, Indian Agent, Portage la Prairie, Manitoba.

Water for Lake St. Martin Day School.

The contents of your letter have been discussed with the Director and it has been decided to act in accordance with your recommendation and dig a well at this teacherage provided that you are satisfied there is a reasonable chance of obtaining water.

We have had unfortunate experiences in the past with the digging of deep and expensive wells on the Prairies. It is realized that it is almost impossible to place a limit beyond which the well should not be dug because of the cost. Therefore, this depth will have to be decided by you in consultation with the contractor, Mr. Mills. His experience at Little Saskatchewan Reserve should prove helpful.

Please advise us of the progress of this well digging.

May 16, 1947.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

Mr. Gow, Department Engineer, Winnipeg, called me on the telephone on the 13th, relative to the surveying of a new school site, Lake St. Martin Reserve. I called on Mr. Gow yesterday, also Mr. Inspector Hamilton, regarding this work. In neither Mr. Inspector Hamilton's nor Mr. Gow's letter is the matter made plain. Is it the Department's intention to build two schools? I take it that at the present time it is the intention to build a combined school and teacherage this summer and to employ two teachers. Both teachers will reside at the proposed school residence for the present and the old log school will be operated in addition to the new school. I would strongly recommend the combination school and residence. At Lake St. Martin Reserve two schools are required and should be placed about 1½ to 2 miles apart for the convenience of the children. The old residence, that was burnt down, is at the approximate centre of the reserve. A well was drilled at this point and could not be used for either school, if it is the intention to build two schools. This would mean that two new wells would have to be drilled.

It has been arranged with Mr. Gow to proceed to Lake St. Martin Reserve on June 2nd. In the meantime I would be pleased to receive advice in connection with this matter, so that the survey may be satisfactorily carried out.

J. Waite,
Indian Agent.

With reference to your memoranda of May 1st and June 2nd relative to the above, I may say that Mr. Gow was requested on May 9th last to arrange for a member of his staff to make an investigation and survey of the proposed school site and to report thereon as soon as possible.
