Memo to Mr. D. B. Gow

Re: Lake St. Martin Indian School Sites

The sites visited for the proposed Lake St. Martin Day School were firstly just above the Narrows on Narrows Reserve No. 49, close to the Anglican Church, and secondly, about a mile to the southwest - both within a hundred yards of the lake shore and both selected by Mr. Waite, the Indian Agent.

The sites are located on knolls of grassed areas away from other buildings, clear of the bush and chosen by Mr. Waite to be central and suitable for the children located in houses along the shoreline of the reserve. The surface soil is sandy loam and short grass forms a tough turf. Underlying this is a sandy clay subsoil with a few scattered stones one to four inches long. This subsoil is well consolidated so that a man took 1½ hours to go down 1½ feet with a post-hole auger after the first foot was dug out. This type of sandy clay has been found to go to a depth of 20 feet or more all over this area. A second hole on the first site was dug out 2½ feet deep in one-half an hour. No water is encountered in the vicinity as vegetable pits keep dry when dug to 5 or 6 feet depths, so that foundation conditions would be good.

No Indian house has a well and only at one place has a very limited supply of water been obtained in boring for wells. Other holes have been dug with bores up to 30 feet deep and deeper wells are sixty. Lake water is generally used for domestic and stock use. Ice blocks are used to some extent. For this reason the Agent considered it inadvisable to have any sewage disposal system which might contaminate the lake nearby.

There is no electric transmission line closer than Ste. Rose, over 50 miles to the southwest, and no electric current is generated on this reserve.

Drinking water is obtainable at a drilled well about 1800 feet south. This well has a limited supply of about four barrels per day and was used by the former teacher. This well supply was the only successful bore of several tried and is located in an enclosure which contains the foundation of the burned-out teacher's residence. The well casing should be surrounded by concrete block 6 feet high. The drainage away from the bore should be made by building up soil around the platform block. A 6" standard casing was put down 37 feet when water was located in gravel. Pumping was done to lower the water in the casing to the bottom and it took 1½ hours to rise 8 feet. The pump cylinder is 20 feet below the surface and static level is 10 feet below the surface, according to information supplied by the local Farm Instructor.

For concrete foundation work, beach gravel may be had 1½ miles from either site.

D. B. Gow, Esq.,
District Chief Engineer,
Department of Mines and Resources,
532 Dominion Public Building,
WINNIPEG, Manitoba.

(b) Duplicate prints showing the proposed School Site #1, together with key plan of the reserve,

(c) Blue prints, in duplicate, showing the proposed School Site #2.

Upon the receipt of your letter of May 9 with reference to the inspection of the site, we got in touch with Mr. Weite, Indian Agent for the district at Portage la Prairie, but he had not received any notification of the inspection from his own department. Inasmuch as he was of the opinion that two schools should be built rather than the one, the visit to the reserve had to be delayed until such time as the matter could be referred back to his own department at Ottawa. Naturally the selection of a site or sites would be governed by the consideration as to whether there should be one or two schools and now I understand that two schools are being considered.

The data given in Mr. Rose's memorandum, supplemented by the sketch plans forwarded, provide the information requested in your letter of May 9. You will appreciate our notification to the draft dated July 6 that the only underground water supply procurable to date is located about 1500 feet from the proposed #1 site or at the location of the burned teacher's residence. This matter of water supply should be a determining feature in the selection of a site or sites and also as to whether there should be one or two schools. The water of Lake St. Martin is unsafe and usually unfit for human consumption and before any school is constructed, an underground water supply must be assured in the immediate vicinity.

Dear Mr. Bryce:

I have for answer your letter of October 29th.

I regret very much that we have been unable to erect a new day school at Lake St. Martin this year. As you are probably aware, the sum of $8,000.00 was included in our main estimates this year for the construction of a one room day school and teacherage for this Reserve. Inspector Hamilton and the Indian Agent did their best to interest contractors in the construction of this school. The only tender that they were able to obtain was that of Mr. R. Sigurdson of Winnipeg, Manitoba. His tender was for $16,410.00 and was submitted to our Surveys and Engineering Branch for their comments.

The reply which we received from this Branch read in part as follows:

"This service has no hesitation in stating that tenders for a one room schools where cost will proximate $16,000.00 are exorbitant and no contract should be awarded".

In view of this statement from our architects and because we were have this identical building constructed elsewhere for prices ranging from $11,000.00 to $13,000.00, we could not accept Mr. Sigurdson's tender. Inspector Hamilton and Mr. Indian Agent Waite were informed of this fact.

However, we have been able to arrange for a suitable boarding place for Mrs. Beachell and also to provide for daily transportation to the school for her. It is our intention to include a revote of $14,000.00 in our next year's appropriation for the construction of this school. It is hoped that we can interest a contractor for its erection next year.
I know that you will be pleased to hear of the two qualified teachers whom we have engaged for the Fairford schools. I feel confident that with their wide experience they will render us efficient service.

In reply to Department letter above noted, I beg to suggest that the Lake St. Martin Day School be closed for the two months indicated, January and February.

The plans of the proposed school at Lake St. Martin Reserve, which were forwarded to Mr. Sigurdson were returned here and I forwarded them to Mr. Herman Helgason of Ashern for an Estimate. "It will be noted that the only source of drinking water is from a well with a limited supply of about four (4) barrels a day situated about 1500 feet from No. 1 site and presumably about 3780 feet from No. 2 site. As the expense of installing a pumping installation from the existing well to either site could obviously not be justified, it would appear that water required for drinking purposes at either site would have to be hauled from the well periodically to a storage tank, which should be installed in the schools".

We are quite determined not to locate any school unless we are assured of a good source of water. Past experience has indicated the wisdom of being assured of a water supply before the construction of a school begins.
Therefore, it would seem evident that steps will have to be taken with regard to the sinking of a well before any further consideration can be given to the request for tenders. In view of your knowledge of local conditions, it would be appreciated if we could be advised as to the obtaining of an underground water supply.

Under separate cover you have already been forwarded a copy of the blueprints for a standard one room school with attached teacher's residence which we intend building at this place. I beg to acknowledge receipt of Department letter above noted, and wish to advise that Mr. Gow's report was attached to Department letter of June 24th, 1947. This letter was answered on September 10th.

The present well, at the old school site on this reserve, gives about 20 pails a day. The water runs in slowly and is being used by the Indians. This would be sufficient water for the school and teacher's residence, but would not accommodate the Indians in addition.

My understanding is that it is the intention of the Department to build one school this summer and another in the near future. If this is correct, the new school this summer should be built at the south site and a well should be drilled. I think water should be obtained at the south site between 80 and 100 feet. The site is slightly rolling and approximately one mile from the old school site. The depth at which water should be obtained is more guess work than anything. The depth of wells vary considerably in the immediate district, from 58 feet to 150 feet. The well should be drilled before any work is done on the school, as there is every possibility of a running well in such close proximity to the lake. Any overflow can be taken care of if drilled before anything is done on the building of the school.

If it is intended that only one school is to be built on the reserve, then the old site should be chosen. It is fairly central, but it would mean that children remote from the site would have to walk 4½ miles. If the south school was built this year, the old school would acco-
date the children from the north end of the reserve for another year or two. However, it would mean two teachers, one of whom would have to walk from the old school to the residence to be built on the new school. The present teacher, Mrs. Beagell is very difficult to get along with. None of the Department nurses have been able to live with her even for a few days at a time, and I am doubtful of an arrangement where two women would have to live together for quite some time.

Will you kindly advise further in this matter regarding the intention of the Department in the matter of erecting one or two schools.

Re: Lake St. Martin

If you refer to Mr. Waite's letter (March 4, 1948, file 126-7-5) you will notice that he recommends two schools. He wishes to avoid transportation.

The enrolment of 51 pupils as recorded in the last quarterly return (December 1947) seems to justify this stand. On checking the treaty list I find 51 pupils 1 to 6 and 52 - 7 to 16. These figures check fairly well with the last census (1944) which give 56 and 44 respectively.

Enclosed please find a map of the reserve. The pencilled "X" is the approximate location of the present school. It is fairly central and is about four miles from the East and West boundaries. Distances appear to be road distances which are longer than that indicated on the map, due to many detours which are necessary due to low lands. This distance will be shortened when the road program is carried out.

The two new schools would be about one mile East of the present school and one mile West. The population is grouped mostly in the centre of the reserve. There are about eight families living near the West boundary, that would be over three miles from the centre and four families, living near the East boundary, that would be over three miles away.

I believe that a central two-room school would provide educational facilities to this community for many years. Briefly, the advantages of a two-room school over two, one-room schools, would be as follows:

Advantages of two, one-room schools:
1. Will bring the East and West boundary families within three miles from the school.
2. Possibly avoid the necessity of transportation.

Advantages of one, two-roomed school:
1. Less expensive to construct than two, one-room schools.
2. Would avoid the necessity to drill two new wells. There is a well at the central location.

The educational setup of a two-room day school was discussed with Provincial Inspector Simms who concurs with our opinion of its advantages over the double proposition. Mr. Waite suggested the two schools to conform to the policy of "no transportation".

May 22, 1948.

Mr. J. Waite,
Field Agent, Indian Affairs,
536 Dominion Public Building,
Winnipeg, Manitoba.

Lake St. Martin Indian Day School

Reference your 206-4B (127) of May 17.

This will acknowledge receipt of bill of materials for two-room Indian Day School at Lake St. Martin. In view of Mr. Doucet's recommendations, we are transferring money from Valley River (where we intended to erect a two-room school) to Lake St. Martin (where we intended to erect a one-room school). This change in plans means that we will have funds for a two-room school at Lake St. Martin and for a one-room school at Valley River.

It is anticipated that we will be receiving from you in the near future a tender for the labour on the construction of this building. In the meantime we cannot place the entire order for the bill of materials until Ministerial approval as to the contractor is obtained. However, we are ordering the cement immediately so that there will be no delay with the excavation of the basement and the pouring of the concrete. If the contractor could give an indication as to the approximate cost of the lumber required for the concrete forms we could authorize local purchase of this amount, so that work could begin on the basement almost as soon as we have Ministerial approval for the labour tender.

Therefore, we are today forwarding to the Departmental Purchasing Agent a requisition for the purchase...
of 700 bags of cement. It is presumed that we will also hear from you with regard to local purchase of the gravel required. I would also like to know if we should forward an accountable advance of $500.00 to you in order to cover hauling and other local charges.

Bernard F. Henry,
Superintendent of Education.

OTTAWA, June 14, 1948.

REQUEST FOR THE CLERK OF THE PRIVY COUNCIL:

Requesting authority for the provision of a combined two-room Indian day school and teachers' residence on the Lake St. Martin Indian Reserve, Portage la Prairie Indian Agency, Province of Manitoba, for which funds are provided in the 1948-49 estimates. Two extra copies of Order-in-Council are required.
June 14, 1948.

TO HIS EXCELLENCY

THE GOVERNOR GENERAL IN COUNCIL,

The undersigned has the honour to report:

THAT it is immediately necessary, and funds are provided in the 1948-49 estimates, Indian Affairs Branch, Mines and Resources, to construct a combined two-room Indian day school and teachers' residence on the Lake St. Martin Indian Reserve, Portage la Prairie Indian Agency, Province of Manitoba;

THAT it is essential that educational facilities be provided for the Indian children on the Lake St. Martin Indian Reserve and living quarters for two Indian day school teachers;

THAT Section 36 of the Public Works Act, Chapter 166, R.S.C., 1927, provides, in part as follows:

"Whenever any works are to be executed under the direction of any Department of the Government the minister having charge of such Department shall invite tenders by public advertisement for the execution of such works except in cases (a) of pressing emergency in which delay would be injurious to the public interest . . . ."

THAT efforts have been made to interest builders and contractors in the vicinity of the said reserve but the builders and contractors have advised that they would not be interested in tenders if invited as aforesaid, as they have all the work they can do in their own localities;

THAT a competent building contractor, namely Norman Belgaon, of Ashern, Manitoba, whom our officials state to be a reliable contractor, has agreed to undertake the construction of the said building immediately on a straight labour contract of Seven Thousand Two Hundred and Fifty Dollars ($7,250.00) with the Department supplying all materials;

THAT it is considered that the construction of this building is a pressing emergency and within the exception provided in Section 36 above recited and further, it is considered that the work can be more expeditiously and economically executed as suggested herein.

The undersigned, therefore, recommends that authority be granted for the provision of this building as outlined above, this being the only arrangement possible at the present time and it being essential that this work be undertaken at once and carried to completion in order that the building will be available for use by the time the next school term commences.

Respectfully submitted,

Minister of Mines and Resources.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Lake St. Martin Indian Day School.

Included in our main estimates for the year 1948-49 was the sum of $14,000.00 for the erection of a one room Indian day school and attached teacher's residence on the Lake St. Martin Indian Reserve, Portage la Prairie Indian Agency, Province of Manitoba.

Before erecting this school we had an educational survey carried out by our Supervisor of Vocational Training. We were of the impression here that a two room school should be erected and this feeling has now been confirmed by Mr. Boulet's report. It has been decided to transfer funds from the Valley River Day School and to erect a two room school at Lake St. Martin instead of the one room school originally planned.

We are, therefore, forwarding today to the Departmental Purchasing Agent a bill of materials for the erection of such a school.

Please find attached a copy of a tender from Mr. Herman Helgason of Ashern, Manitoba, for all the labour work connected with this school. Normally the construction of a school costs us between $25,000.00 and $30,000.00 depending upon its location. We have an estimate from North American Lumber and Supply Company on the bill of materials for this school amounting to approximately
$9,000.00. With Mr. Helgason's labour contract of $7,250.00, we should be able to erect the school for approximately $20,000.00.

We feel that Mr. Helgason's tender is a satisfactory one and have, therefore, prepared the Order in Council as indicated above.

Director.

Mr. Hoey's memorandum of June 14/48
File 126-7-5 (E)

We have copy of P.C. 2869 dated 26th ultimo covering the contract of Herman Helgason of Ashern, Manitoba, for construction of the above building at $7250.00, and were advised that no action on our part in connection with this work is necessary.

However, we also have the tender of North American Lumber & Supply Co., Ltd., who offer to supply the material except the door and sash hardware, blackboards, cabinets, stairs, gravel, and sand at $9014.72, f.o.b. Winnipeg.

Your requisition also states that the Ashern Supply Company of Ashern, Manitoba, are interested in tendering on these supplies. Have you or the Indian Agent received this Firm's tender?

As the expenditure involved is in excess of $5,000.00, will you please arrange to submit the usual recommendation to Council covering the purchase of this material.

W. M. Vincent,
Departmental Purchasing Agent.

TO HIS EXCELLENCY

THE GOVERNOR GENERAL IN COUNCIL,

The undersigned has the honour to report:

THAT funds are provided in the 1948-49 appropriation, Indian Affairs Branch, Mines and Resources, to construct a combined two-room Indian Day School and teachers' residence on the Lake St. Martin Indian Reserve, Portage la Prairie Indian Agency, Province of Manitoba;

THAT authority has already been granted by P.C. 2869, June 26, 1948, to engage the services of Herman Helgason to construct the said building;

THAT every endeavour has been made to obtain quotations from various firms for materials required for the building;

THAT the Departmental Purchasing Agent has received a tender from the North American Lumber and Supply Company, Limited, who are a reliable firm. They offer to supply the material, except the doors and dash hardware, blackboards, cabinets, stairs, gravel and sand at a cost of $9,014.72, f.o.b. Winnipeg;

THAT the Purchasing Agent considers the price quoted to be fair and reasonable.

The undersigned, therefore, recommends that authority be granted for the acceptance of the tender of the North American Lumber and Supply Company, Limited, to supply the materials on which they have quoted a price of $9,014.72, f.o.b. Winnipeg, as it is essential that the materials be purchased at the earliest possible date in order to allow the erection of the building to proceed.

Respectfully submitted,

Minister of Mines and Resources.

The undersigned has the honour to report:

THAT funds are provided in the 1948-49 appropriation, Indian Affairs Branch, Mines and Resources, to construct a combined two room Indian Day School and teachers' residence on the Lake St. Martin Indian Reserve, Portage la Prairie Indian Agency, Province of Manitoba;

THAT authority has already been granted by P.C. 2869, June 26, 1948, to engage the services of Herman Helgason to construct the said building;

THAT every endeavour has been made to obtain quotations from various firms for materials required for the building;

THAT the Departmental Purchasing Agent has received a tender from the North American Lumber and Supply Company, Limited, who are a reliable firm. They offer to supply the material, except the door and sash hardware, blackboards, cabinets, stairs, gravel and sand at a cost of $9,533.26, f.o.b. Winnipeg;

THAT the Purchasing Agent considers the price quoted to be fair and reasonable.

The undersigned, therefore, recommends that authority be granted for the acceptance of the tender of the North American Lumber and Supply Company, Limited, to supply the materials on which they have quoted a price of $9,533.26, f.o.b. Winnipeg, as it is essential that the materials be purchased at the earliest possible date in order to allow the erection of the building to proceed.

Respectfully submitted,

The Committee of the Privy Council have had before them a report dated 11th September, 1943, from the Minister of Mines and Resources, representing:

THAT funds are provided in the 1948-49 appropriation, Indian Affairs Branch, Mines and Resources, to construct a combined two room Indian Day School and teachers' residence on the Lake St. Martin Indian Reserve, Portage la Prairie Indian Agency, Province of Manitoba;

THAT authority has already been granted by Order in Council P.C. 2669, June 26, 1943, to engage the services of Norman Helgason to construct the said building;

THAT every endeavour has been made to obtain quotations from various firms for materials required for the building;

THAT the Departmental Purchasing Agent has received a tender from the North American Lumber and Supply Company, Limited, who are a reliable firm, in which they offer to supply the material, except the doors and some hardware, blackboards, cabinets, stairs, gravel and sand at a cost of $9,453.26, f.o.b., Winnipeg;

The Committee, therefore, on the recommendation of the Minister of Mines and Resources, advise that authority be granted for the acceptance of the tender of the North American Lumber and Supply Company, Limited, to supply the materials on which they have quoted a price of $9,453.26, f.o.b., Winnipeg, as it is essential that the materials be purchased at the earliest possible date in order to allow the erection of the building to proceed.

Further to our conversation, please be advised that the following minor structural changes will be necessary in the blue prints provided for this school:

(1) The stairs from the teachers' living quarters to their bedrooms should be straightened out to remove the landing. This is due to the fact that the hand rail at the foot of the stairs is too high to permit the passage of furniture between it and the ceiling. By eliminating the landing, we will allow more space in the living-room and also will be able to take large pieces of furniture upstairs more easily. The Contractor at one of our other construction projects did this by putting in fourteen steps and by raising them 8" apart.

(2) On Sheet No. 3 of Plan # 849, you will note that the door in the closet to the left hand bedroom is so situated that it hits the sloping ceiling of the bedroom when it is opened. This can easily be removed by moving the door 3" to the right.
Under separate cover I am mailing you another set of the blueprints and two sets of specifications. As our stock is depleted and it will be necessary to run off a new batch of prints, would you please obtain an extra set from Mr. Davis' office.

Re: Furnace New School Lake St. Martin.

On receiving the blue prints for the above school I immediately tried to get quotations on a furnace as per specifications. I called on Ashdown's, Marshall-Wells, General Steel Wares, Eaton's, Imperial Iron Corporation and Dufault Sheet Metal.

No one could supply a cast iron furnace and no promise could be made when one of 200,000 capacity could be made available. It was stated definitely nothing could be done this year. Another real problem was the shortage of sheet metal. In this respect Mr. Dufault gave some glimmer of hope.

I attach a cut showing the only large furnace I could locate in Winnipeg. These furnaces are in urgent demand and Mr. Argue could not hold one pending a reply - thus the need for your immediate decision.

You will note Mr. Dufault has been good enough to undertake this work, but he is short of sheet metal. Is there any way the Department can get released to Mr. Dufault the metal listed on his quotation? The quotation is only good pending the release of metal.

Mr. Helgason already is asking for the pipes for the partitions to the upstairs and these should be supplied at the earliest possible date.
I am concerned because I do not believe another furnace is available in Winnipeg and I am sure the one proposed will give service.

Please wire re accepting and what action has been taken re supplying the sheet metal.

A.G. Hamilton,

DEFICIENCIES AND IRRREGULARITIES TO BE MADE GOOD AT THE LAKE ST. MARTIN INDIAN SCHOOL, Manitoba.

1. Basement Wall & Floor Surfaces are to be rubbed down as provided for under Concrete Finish on Page 20. Wire ends are to be bent into wall to help key the patching. Patching is to be done after wall is wetted and brushed with neat cement wash. Mortar or one cement to two parts sand should have just enough water added to make mixture workable. Use lake water.

2. Basement Floor Drains - Grilles are to be set flush or slightly below floor level on a ledge to be formed or concrete inside present opening. Use one cement to three sand and insert wood blocks on edge to receive screws of grilles. Keep lower openings to drain pipes clear of cement.

3. Floor Edges are to have cove floor mould laid in Tremco and screwed down every two feet by ¼ inch screws and Rawl Plugs.

4. Furnace Room and Dispensary First-Aid - Partitions are to have plates on floor and studs along concrete walls where no wood bucks have been placed. Plates are to be bolted in place.

5. Spaces around all windows and doors are to be filled flush with tightly packed mineral wool and nails are to be driven into wood to hold any patches of concrete and mortar necessary.

6. Chimney. Pointing of joints is to be filled flush with cement mortar after brick is brushed and thoroughly wetted with water. Chimney precast caps are to be cured at least three days before being placed on chimney. Build saddles (crickets), as shown. After placing, any damage is to be made good promptly. Boarding is to be nailed to both roof ridge and at nailers to replace shingles. Any holes or gouges in shingles must be filled with caulking compound asphalt. Flashing must have seal asphalt caulking compound filling forced into brick joints after aluminum nails have been driven into the brick joints until nail heads are flush with brickwork and spaced every four inches, approximately.

7. Furnace Room. Doors are to be made of shiplap and covered with galvanized iron as specified.

Outside Catchbasin. This is to be built according to the plan and have an inside bottom level six (6) inches below the present end of the outlet pipe which will reach just flush inside the wall and be watertight (particularly under the inlet pipe). An outlet thimble is to be set at the same level as the inlet and facing the lake. Both pipes are to be temporarily plugged with bags of linseed by Mr. Farel. The lid is to have battens top and bottom. This work must be done without freezing concrete before installation. The contractor may do this in the spring, if materials are stored for this purpose.

Outside Concrete Walls. Smoothing is to be done but no cement is to be applied until frost is absent.

Kitchen - is to have (a) - stove where dresser is shown. Asbestos board is to go on wall.

(b) - Sink unit against classroom partition with cupboard section on top to ceiling. Unit is bought.

(c) - Dresser on wall where sink is shown but clear of window. This unit is made to follow plan.

Chimney jointing is to be filled flush in all joints to roof top. Exterior brickwork requires weathered joints.

Attic trusses are to be knee-braced as soon as 2" x 4" arrives and gussets, if not in, are to be placed under ridge and at bottom of

Attention: Mr. B. F. Neary,

I am enclosing herewith a Progress Report on the Lake St. Martin School. This man has not followed out the specifications, but he has been instructed to make the necessary changes. However, he has plenty of work done to cover this additional $2000.00 and I recommend payment be made.

Last week, I visited Lake St. Martin 2 room school, which is under construction, with Mr. Ross of the Surveys and Engineering Branch, and I am forwarding you a list of work that Mr. Helgason, the Contractor has not done according to specifications. The shiplap on the main walls of the building on the inside has not been done as specified - it has been nailed straight around the building in place of putting it diagonally. While the building would have been stronger if it had been put on diagonally, nothing can be done at this late date.

Mr. Hamilton has visited this school practically every week this summer, but as far as I can see has done nothing but make social calls. I advised Mr. Helgason that final payment will not be made until such time as these changes are made.

Lake St. Martin Indian Day School.

Please find attached a self-explanatory letter concerning Miss A. M. Jones, who is interested in the position of senior teacher at the school now under construction.

Have you given any thought as yet to the furniture which will be required for this new teachers' residence? I am attaching a copy of our standard list of furnishings for a one-room school. It is only necessary to equip a second bedroom for a two-room school. Therefore, if you have not already done so, would you prepare a requisition based on this list so that there will be no delays when the school is finished before we are ready to have it operating.

I would ask you also to advise me concerning desks, janitor supplies, etc., which will be required. In fact, we must do everything possible to anticipate the opening of this school and to order such equipment now.

If preparing the furniture requisition, please order rugs, curtains, etc., in colours which will match the colour schemes of the various rooms. You will also have to check the size of the linoleum rugs to ensure that they fit the rooms.

[Signature]

Bernard F. Henry,

A visit was made by writer to the above school on April 12th in company with Mr. Waite of the Indian Affairs Branch and an inspection was made of the work done.

In the Basement:

Finishing of walls and floors remains to be done. Doors are to be made and hung. Windows are to be hinged and fitted with transom chains, locks and chain raising attachments. Storms are to have brackets attached. Other finishing is to be done and painting completed.

The furnace work is completed but the draft controls are to be carried to a fixed plate upstairs and one cold air entry is to be made into the south basement room. This type of furnace takes so much space it would be advisable to have any future school built to this plan changed so that the furnace room would be 3 feet wider. At present there is no way to get at the smoke pipe for cleaning or replacement except by removing one cold air pipe which blocks access space at present.

First Floor Classrooms:

Blackboards, cupboard door frames and a minor amount of work on the trims and window shelves remain to be done. Painting has not been started. The floors require sanding before varnishing.

Living Quarters:

The dresser remains to be built and installed. All trim and floors require sanding before painting. Chimney beading and plastering over the brick besides all crackfilling, here and in the school rooms, are to be done before painting can be carried on.

A vent should be cut and trimmed for the chemical toilet.

Exterior Finish:

Chimney capping and painting of the flashing around the chimneys are to be done. Flashing is to be completed along water stop. All painting is to be done. Toilets are to be put on sills and placed. The outside catchbasin is to be built at junction of drains from basement rooms.

It is estimated this work will amount to about $2,000. It was found, on a visit to the contractor in his home at Ashorn, that he planned to proceed on Monday with his workmen to complete the work as rapidly as possible. He expects a payment to be made him on account. It seems reasonable that he receive an amount which would leave $2,000. to be paid on completion of the work.

Mr. D. B. Gow,

532 Dominion Public Building,
WINNIPEG, Manitoba.

Mr. H.S. Davis,
Regional Supervisor,
WINNIPEG, Manitoba.

Dear Mr. Davis:

Re Van South end Lake St Martin school.

At the South end of Lake St Martin reserve are about 6 children who have several miles to go to the Lake St Martin School. The roads are bad on this reserve, and it was recommended by the Indians that Dave Traverse, who resides there and has a good team, be allowed $35.00 per month to drive these children to and from school each day.

It is expected that school attendance will be very poor from this end unless a van is employed, and yet it does not warrant a new school, and probably, will not for some time.

We would be pleased to be advised if authority could be secured to pay Dave for driving the children to school at the above rate.

Yours very truly,

D.A.H. Reid
A/Superintendent.

Referring to your letter of May 6th No 259,815/1. I beg to report as follows:

I visited Little Grand Rapids School on July 23rd and found a log building, with the seams between the logs open to the weather, situated outside the reserve near to the Hudson Bay Fort.

Mr Johnston was in charge as Teacher.

I enquired of the Councillor and Bandif the people would remain in the vicinity of the school during the summer months, and was told that the people were only there to receive their annuity and supplies after which they would remove to their usual fishing and hunting stations some distance from the reserve.

There is only one house in the reserve at present.

The Councillor asked for biscuits for the children attending the school, but I informed him that, not knowing the school was in operation biscuits had not been estimated for.

The Band asked to have a school built for them in the reserve, I pointed out to them that before this could be done it would be necessary for the people to be established in homes upon their reserve.

The building now in use is not fit in its present condition to be used as a school at any season of the year.

I think under the circumstances a summer school at Little Grand Rapids is waste of time and money, and would respectfully recommend that after the present season is past it be discontinued until such time as the improvements warrant expenditure.

your obedient servant

Dear Sir,

Replying to yours of the 19th, No. 269818/1 re the qualifications of the teachers at Little Grand Rapids, Pekangekum and Deer Lake:

I have delayed answering until I received a report of the work done in the schools. I requested the Rev. Mr. Barner to make a special report of the schools on the river and this is incorporated in my reply.

Alex Murdoch who is teaching at Deer Lake, Ontario, is a graduate of Brandon Industrial School and has a pretty fair education. He has had one year's experience teaching at Nelson Lake. Mr. Barner reports of him as follows: "I visited the school at Deer Lake on the 19th of July, 1918, and found 15 children present. Mr. Alex Murdoch, a graduate of Brandon School in charge. He commenced work on June 17th and up-to-date has had an average attendance of 10. This will increase when the Cranes arrive from Sandy Lake. I was much impressed with Alex's ability to teach these children. He certainly has the genius though not the professional training of a teacher. The children are well behaved and diligent. The building belongs to the people and the church. It is made of logs well covered up. The roof is made of heavy poles covered with tar paper. The walls inside are made of heavy poles covered with hewn poles. The floor is made of whippoorwill lumber. There are no desks. The seats are homemade. The school equipment is much better than at Little Grand Rapids. There is an overplus of slates which we are sending to the school at Little Grand Rapids."

Alexander Crate is at Pekangekum. He has had a good general education in English. Has a good general knowledge of trading and business and is splendidly suitable for Pekangekum School. Mr. Barner did not visit this school.
Mrs. Mary Nanakup teacher at Little Grand Rapids is a graduate of this school and has a good general education in English. Mr. Barner visited the school on the 12th of July and reports as follows: "I found a good building made of logs, well roofed but not chinked or plastered in any way. There were 40 children in attendance well behaved and attentive. Mrs. Nanakup (Mary Jane Gibault) a graduate of the Brandon Industrial School was in charge. This woman is evidently a consecrated worker and quite capable of handling a school of this elementary type. The furniture and equipment are very poor. The seats are simply rude logs on legs and there are no desks of any kind. With the few lesson cards and scribblers in stock the teacher was getting very good results in lettering and writing by the pupils. We visited the school again on Monday finding 71 present. We talked to the people about the school in the Sunday services and urged them to send their children."

"I am deeply impressed with what I have seen of the experiment of appointing the educated Indians as teachers of these elementary schools. From the purely economic stand-point it is good business in my judgment for in the case of Deer Lake where, previous to this year, they have had only one summer term of school, the young men who are now freighting can keep notes in their books, do some figuring and some writing in Cree. It seems to be a useless thing to send persons into these schools who do not know the Cree as well as the English for there cannot be a point of contact with the children."

Trusting that the Department will find this report satisfactory, I am

Yours sincerely,

F. Ferrie
Industrial School, Brandon.

LITTLE GRAND RAPIDS.

The summer day schools at Little Grand Rapids, Deer Lake and Pekangekum did not operate this summer, I understand. In fact the work at these several reserves varies in operation so much that it is not very satisfactory from any viewpoint so far as I am able to figure it out. In fact so long as the Indians are of nomadic habits it is doubtful if schools can be of much advantage, as it is very difficult to assemble the children for classes owing to the erratic habits of life of the parents or guardians.

Leaving Bloodvein Indian Reserve on the 17th inst., I proceeded to Bloodvein Indian Reserve on the 18th inst., and remained there until the 24th inst.

At the Bloodvein Indian Reserve there are only two or three families left in the Reserve; the remainder are all away in the bush trapping, but there were no complaints received at the Reserve.

Leaving Bloodvein on the morning of the 25th inst., I patrolled north along the Berens River, arriving at Berens River on the 26th inst.

The police dogs all stood the patrol well excepting Dog No. 56 Jiggs, this dog has never been as good dog as he should be for his age, but since returning to the detachment he is getting stronger again.

The weather during the entire patrol was very cold, on one occasion the temperature dropped to 49 degrees Fahrenheit.

The patrol was engaged for a period of fourteen days, four of which were spent at Little Grand Rapids and one at Bloodvein Indian Reserve, covering a total mileage of approximately 275 miles by dog train.

REPORT

At 8:00 a.m. of the 7th inst., in company with Spec. Const. Felix A., I left the detachment at Berens River Detachment for Little Grand Rapids Indian Reserve.

The route taken going in was approximately 150 miles, which we were four days in traversing, reaching the Little Grand Rapids Reserve on the evening of the 10th.

The Little Grand Rapids Indian Reserve has a population of about 200 Indians. The United Church Mission is located here with a day school and church, also the Roman Catholics have a day-school and mission. The United Church Missionary located here is one Brother Gabriel, who is also supposed to be the teacher, but he hires an unqualified Indian to do the teaching, and he hauls freight for Hudson's Bay Co. from Lake Winnipeg by way of horse-team.

There are two traders located at this reserve, one Hudson's Bay Co. and one Joe Allix an independent trader operating out of Blood River.

While visiting Little Grand Rapids Reserve, while there I held a meeting of the Band Councilors, they had very little to say except that fur was very scarce.

I believe that before spring they would have no furs unless the Department of Indian Affairs would assist them, personally I do not think they could have any fur for the balance of the year, good fur catch before New Year, but now the catch has fallen off, this is due to the extreme cold weather, it was reported by the Chief Mr. Boucher that there was considerable immorality going on among his people, it was stated that a girl named Mary Jane Boucher gave birth to an illegitimate child named Dorothy, and she claims that one Ontario Game Guardian is the father, but was not yet born, and no evidence was presented to inform the Chief that we had better lay until next treaty, when it could be discussed by the Indian Agent, Lewis is a Canadian who is in charge of a post located near Little Grand Rapids Reserve, Lake, Ont.

Dear Sir:

Re Mr. Luther Schuetze, Little Grand Rapids.

In further reply to your letter of February 26th, 1930, - File #125-12-1 - I beg to state that when Mr. Luther Schuetze was appointed as missionary teacher at Little Grand Rapids, he found himself without buildings of any kind on the Reserve. Therefore he had to proceed to erect both school house and residence. Your Department provided material for the school house, and our Board provided material for the mission house, but Mr. Schuetze was entirely responsible for the erection of these buildings. It was impossible for him to accomplish all this work out of school hours without some assistance. Our Board, therefore, provided an Assistant for him in the person of a graduate of the Norway House Residential School. We chose one of the brightest ex-pupils, so that in an emergency he could take charge of the school if there was work which demanded Mr. Schuetze's attention. I know that Mr. Schuetze has given some personal attention to the freighting of the material, but it was not for the Hudson's Bay Company - it was in connection with the school and mission buildings.

I regret that this report, which appears to be of a damaging character, has reached your Department; but I think that if there is a thorough investigation by your Agent, it will show that it is only a half truth and that Mr. Schuetze has had no relationship with the Hudson's Bay Company in the matter of freighting. All the reports we receive in connection with his work are very satisfactory, and I believe that both the Government and the Church are receiving full value for all they are investing in this work.

Our Mr. Barner expects to visit Little Grand Rapids during the coming summer and he will report further to me in connection with the work there.

Very sincerely yours,

The bulk of the time taken in this freighting operation was the Christmas holidays; but, in addition to this, he lost twelve school days to the work. During these twelve school days he left the school in charge of an assistant who was provided by the Mission Board. This young man is a graduate of the Norway House Boarding School and is thoroughly qualified to take charge of the school for a few days. The report that Mr. Schuetze was freighting for the Hudson Bay Company is entirely without foundation, for he did not handle a pound of their freight during the operation.

In view of the fact that Mr. Schuetze has had to take charge of the erection of two buildings since he went into Little Grand Rapids, and that he has had to perform most of the mechanical work himself, I think that he has accomplished something very fine. I feel sure that on our part, instead of entering into criticism, we ought to commend him highly for his self-sacrificing labours.

Trusting that this explanation will be quite satisfactory to the Department, I remain

THE NEW OUTLOOK

Report of journey up the Berens River, Manitoba

by ARTHUR BARNER

Rev. J. W. Nickle and I left Berens River Mission with two of our Christian Indians, John James and William Everett, at seven o'clock Thursday, July 18th. We took a fifteen-foot canoe with Evinrude engines and a supply of gasoline and oil. We had a good outfit and a good supply of food. As we expected to be away three weeks, it was necessary to take everything needed to the far end of the journey by freight, to be ready for our return.

Our first stop was Little Grand Rapids, about 100 miles inland. This point is 200 feet above the waters of Lake Winnipeg, so we will have to remember that we had to portage canoe and goods thirty-eight times on the journey, each portage covering a range of rapids. The water was high and the rapids turbulent; our expert canoe men took everything in their stride. After three days' steady travel we reached Little Grand Rapids at 6:30 p.m. on Saturday, July 20th.

It is four years since I visited this place. The following statement will refer to the Indians living at Little Grand Rapids, Pekanepegum and Deer Lake. When I first visited those places in 1923, there was no mission work as far as mission work was concerned. For about fifteen years prior to that time, Rev. Mr. Nickle, of Berens River Mission, had made annual visits in the summer to Little Grand Rapids and Deer Lake. He did all that he could that was possible of the Christian religion in the course of two or three days. This policy was continued under Rev. W. Nickle's care each year after 1920, including Pekanepegum. But it seemed that the Indians were not interested for the people. In July, 1927, a well-educated man named Luther Schwartze, came five days to see us. He was doing with the Indians at Poplar River, felt moved to go and open the work at Little Grand Rapids. He saw much of God in transforming things there. At very small cost the Church and the Government had built a school, house and mission house. He and his family are a great example to the people behind him. The Indians here are 281 souls in the band. He has gathered 150 into the Church of Christ, and his school attendance is very good. He is showing the people by his garden what can be done with vegetables, and by keeping goats to provide milk for his six children and his faithful wife. His children are very good, and he keeps them as good subordinates. These people left an income of $1,000 last year, and they are prospering, and they feel sure they have been led of the Spirit. We spent Sunday with Brother Schwartze at Deer Lake and their store, holding two services in the schoolhouse, which was uncomfortably crowded. We had a very hearty congregation of the birthday of the Church, though we thought that it would show up better going inside.
Sir:

It was brought to my attention last week that Miss Mary Mozel has been hired by Mr. Luther Scheutze to teach the classroom on the Little Grand Rapids Indian Reserve.

I discussed this matter with Mr. Irwin, the Indian Agent at Selkirk, who stated that he was aware Mr. Scheutze hired Miss Mozel last year to substitute while he was sick, but he did not know she had again returned last September.

I phoned the Rev. Dr. Cormie, of the United Church, who supervises these appointments, and although he was aware of Miss Mozel being at Little Grand Rapids, he understood she was hired by Mr. Scheutze to teach his own children and expected she was paid from a grant allowed for education by the church. He immediately wrote Mr. Scheutze, instructing him to carry on the work himself and dispense with the services of Miss Mozel in connection with the teaching of the Indian children. Dr. Cormie was very emphatic in his instructions and he is positive they will be carried out. At any rate, he intends to make a thorough investigation of the whole matter.

I have always received good reports in connection with the work carried on by Mr. Scheutze and I have every reason to believe that Dr. Cormie's instructions will be followed out. Any further developments regarding this matter will be reported.

Your obedient servant,

A.G. Hamilton

Dear Sir:

I have for acknowledgment your letters of February 17th, Files 125-30-1 and 125-12-1, relative to school terms and attendance at the U.C. and R.C. Schools at Little Grand Rapids.

In the case of the U.C. school, the attendance during the December, 1940 Quarter was very good, considering that I have given instructions that all able-bodied Indians were to leave the Reserve for their trap lines.

I believe the poor attendance at the R.C. School was due largely to the fact that the Missionary reported a little trouble between the parents and himself. This was purely a personal quarrel and the parents refused to allow their children to attend school. I wrote the R.G.M.P. at Berens River and instructed him to talk to these Indians when he made his patrol to the Reserve; this patrol has been made and I understand that trouble is now under control. I also wrote Mr. Street, Teacher of the U.C. School and requested that he not accept Mr. Bellavance's pupils in his school. Street replied that he would do as I requested.

In regard to the matter of school terms, both teachers agreed at Treaty time that the months of March, April and May would be the best to have the schools closed. I cannot understand why the U.C. School had such poor attendance last June as most of the Indians are on the Reserve at this time of year. The matter of arranging a satisfactory school term at Little Grand Rapids is indeed a difficult one. The question is, briefly, that there is bound to be poorer attendance during the Winter and Spring if the Indians take their families to the trap lines. It is necessary that the men at least, go to trap lines as this is practically the only means they have of making a livelihood. On the other hand if the women and children stay on the Reserves while their husbands are trapping we would have to issue rations to them. This is a matter where either the school attendance suffers during the Winter months or we keep the Indians on the Reserve and issue rations to them. I have always instructed the Indians to leave their Reserves in the Summer and go to their trap lines. The matter, therefore, of arranging a suitable school term under the circumstances is very difficult. The present school term has been arranged as suggested by the Teachers of both Schools.

Please advise if you wish me to again take this matter up with the teachers.

Very truly yours,

R.A. Hoey, Esq.
Superintendent of Welfare & Training,
Ottawa.

Indian Agent.

I am wondering if it would be possible for me to take July and the first two weeks in August in order that I might attend the University Summer School at Fort Garry site, Winnipeg. In this manner I have worked toward obtaining my B.A. degree and should have my degree within a short time.

I quite realize that July and August are teaching months here but I feel certain that I could slack two weeks in March and possibly most of May without doing any harm so far as the red season is concerned. I doubt if the Indians will be away from here before March 15' due to the unseasonable lateness of the season. Also most of them will likely be back in early May.

I am enclosing a letter which I have just received from Mr. John N. Clark—school teacher at Little Grand Rapids.

I wish to inform you that Mr. N. A. Dusek, reported on July 21, at Little Grand Rapids. He had been delayed considerably by the Selective Service. I do not know what the trouble was, but that was the information he gave me.

I would suggest that he be put on the payroll of Aug. 1, as I do not think he would be able to do much in a week's time. He informed me that he forwarded the papers to the department which I had sent to him some time ago which were to be returned to the department and I explained that he put in his time as stated on July 21st or July, but he was still not started on the 22nd because the school had to be cleaned up before he could start teaching.

I am quite well aware that it is quite hard to get men for this place but personally I do not think that him nor the man sent to Poplar River, would be suitable for the position, as neither one of them understand anything about pulling teeth and handling children.

In my opinion any missionary going out to this reserve should be given a course for six months regarding medicine and work that would be taken up by an Indian teacher and that is why the Roman Catholics make such a success of their missions here when they send them north into Indian country. Dear Doctor Dorsey:

I desire to refer to Mr. Hoey's letter of May 15, with reference to the Little Grand Rapids Indian Day School. When that letter was written, we were under the impression that the United Church and the Roman Catholic Church Schools on the Little Grand Rapids Reserve would close on March 31. However, it now appears that although Mr. Dueck opened the U.C. school on June 1, 1944, the R.C. school was not opened until September 1, 1944. The latter school continued in operation during April and May, and when Mr. Dueck realized this, he also kept the school open during those months.

The Agent now intimates that these two schools should remain in operation until June 30.

We have no particular objection to this arrangement, but I am writing the agent, stating that in order to avoid such difficulties in the future we should revert to the regular academic year, namely, September 1 to the following June 30.

As Mr. Dueck has remained at Little Grand Rapids, we will be prepared to continue salary to him to June 30, but owing to the circumstances about which we have just learned, I think that Mr. Neufeld should not report to the school until September 1, 1946, with the definite understanding that he will continue it in operation until June 30, 1946.

Yours sincerely,

Rev. Geo. Dorsey, D.D.,
Assoc. Sec. Bd. of Home Miss.

Mr. E. McPherson, Indian Agent,
Selkirk, Man.

I have your letter of the 22nd instant, with reference to Mr. Dueck, teacher of the Little Grand Rapids Indian Day School.

In view of the contents of your letter it is necessary to review the situation at both the United Church and the Roman Catholic Schools at Little Grand Rapids.

For some time past it has been understood that these two schools would close at the end of March and re-open at the beginning of June. Mr. Dueck re-opened the Little Grand Rapids School on June 1, 1944, and consequently, at the end of March, 1945, he had been paid 10 months' salary. In view of the previous arrangement his name was then removed from the paylist.

A teacher for the R.C. school was not secured until late in August - see our letter of August 28, 1944. He was placed on the paylist from September 1, 1944, and consequently would not teach the 10 months until the end of June, 1945. In view of the above, no injustice has been done to Mr. Dueck.

I note from your letter that Mr. Dueck has kept the school open during April and May, without any authority, and in the meantime we have received a recommendation from the United Church of Canada to appoint Mr. Abram Neufeld as teacher of this school. As we thought that Mr. Dueck had given up duties at the
end of March and that the two months' annual holidays would be taken during April and May, we advised the United Church authorities to have the new teacher report for duty on June 1.

It is perplexing for the officials of this Branch to be informed at the end of May that the preceding arrangement in effect at this school had not been carried out. It is difficult to understand why we were not previously informed of Mr. Dueck's action.

It is possible that both schools on this reserve should be taught during the same months, but I think the time has come for us to make a definite decision regarding the months during which the schools should be in operation and inform all persons accordingly, and thus avoid the difficulty that has occurred this year.

To carry out the suggestion contained in your postscript would mean that the children would obtain only one month's holidays. I doubt very much if that would be very satisfactory.

If you agree with the statement made by you by Mr. Dueck, to the effect that the children do not attend the school during the months of July and August, I think the best solution of the whole matter is to revert to the regular academic year, namely, September 1 to the following June 30, and this should apply to both schools. Please let me hear from you immediately.

We are again placing Mr. Dueck's name on the pay-list, so that he will receive salary for the months of April and May and June. This is being done with the understanding that the attendance that he will have during those months justifies the payments being made to him.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Ottawa, May 28, 1945.
